title: Introduction to Social Work and Social Welfare
description: This is an introductory course on the concept and meaning of social work and social welfare. It aims to help students understand the role of social welfare in society and the role of social work as a helping profession in social welfare. Course content includes appraising the mission, scope, and functions of social welfare and social work, examining different welfare approaches, and discussing factors giving rise to unmet needs. The relationship between social welfare and other social institutions, and the major types of social welfare services in Hong Kong will also be introduced. Special attention will be given to addressing the plights of vulnerable populations and promoting social justice, and to equip students with foundation knowledge and essential values for the profession of social work.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. understand the mission, scope, goals, and functions of social work and social welfare;  2. comprehend the conceptions and roles of social welfare and social work in the changing society;  3. acquire knowledge on how social welfare and social work contribute to solving social problems and meeting needs under changing social conditions, with emphasis on the plights of vulnerable groups in the society; 4. gain an overview of the development, purpose, scope and content of social welfare services in Hong Kong; 5. understand social work as helping profession in social welfare, including its value and knowledge base, roles and functions, practice principles and methods; and 6. acquire foundation knowledge and essential values for the profession of social work.
syllabus: 1. What is social work?  2. What is social welfare? 3. Relationship between social work and social welfare 4. The roles of social welfare and social work in the changing society 5. Social welfare and social work in Hong Kong 6. Social welfare and social work practice in selected countries

title: Self-development in Changing Society
requirements: Not for students who have taken SOWK1150, SOWK2110, UGED1600, UGED2591, GESC2117 or PSYC1030.
description: Hong Kong and the global society are undergoing rapid social change, such as the rising number of nuclear families, post-divorce families and single-parent families; the dwindling of upward mobility opportunities for the young generation; and the increasingly volatile economic outlook due to globalization. In this multi-dimensional society of chaos and uncertainty, the younger generation is prone to confusion and a lack of direction. This course aims to help students who have just reached adulthood to understand personal growth, to develop self-acceptance, to reflect upon their self-identity and to recognize the impact of the rapid changing society on an individual. It is hoped that the course can assist students to develop direction and values in facing various life tasks, prepare them for choices in life path and equip them with a proactive manner in future study / career.
outcome: After studying this course, students will be able to:  1) Acquire basic knowledge on human nature and self development  2) Understand the reciprocal influence between self and environment  3) Identify factors and social forces affecting self development in different aspects  4) Understand the possibilities and challenges in the course of self-development  5) Examine their current values and attitudes related to various life tasks  6) Reflect on their goals and purposes in living in the changing society
syllabus: 1. Introduction: Changing self and changing society -Who are you? Where are you? -Person-in-environment  2. Understand yourself in the changing society : -Psychosocial/developmental perspective  -Humanistic perspective -Cognitive perspective -Psychoanalytic perspective -Behaviorist perspectives -Ecological System Theory -Social Changes and Social Responsibility  3. Developing yourself in context -Death, dying and Bereavement -Values and Meaning in life  -University life & career -Gender Role and Sexuality -Love Relationship  4. Review and Conclusion: Enhancing Self-development

title: From Understanding to Empowering the Socially Disadvantaged
requirements: Not for students who have taken SOWK2190 or UGEC2014.
description: The number of socially disadvantaged people, particularly individuals with disabilities, aged, newly arrived immigrants, ethnic minorities and homeless people, has been increasing rapidly. There are different attitudes towards these socially disadvantaged groups: discrimination, avoidance, sympathy, acceptance and understanding. The course reviews how these attitudes were constructed socially and spread in our society. The course aims to promote students’ reflection and to enhance their understanding on the causes and livelihood of the socially disadvantaged. Experiential learning opportunity such as community visits, community education projects with involvement of the disadvantaged groups in social change are means to be employed to facilitate students’ learning and to achieve the goal of empowerment. Related community resources and methods to improve the well-being of the disadvantaged group will also be discussed. This course is inter-disciplinary in focus, emphasizing social, cultural, historical, and geographical aspects of exclusion and marginalization. Theories of social exclusion, social justice, social construction etc. will be introduced.
outcome: Upon completion of course, the student will be able to:  1. Apply theories of social exclusion, marginalisation, social construction, and empowerment in understanding the situations and livelihoods of the socially disadvantaged groups in Hong Kong;  2. Review the structural causes and societal attitudes leading to social exclusion and marginalization of the socially disadvantaged groups;  3. Reflect on values and attitudes towards the socially disadvantaged groups critically;  4. Practice skills in planning and implementing community education project to empower the socially disadvantaged groups;  5. Identify community resources and practical methods in enhancing the well-being of the socially disadvantaged groups.
syllabus: The core content of this course is as follows:  - Understanding the situations of the socially disadvantaged groups  - Dominant discourses and social construction of social vulnerability and disadvantaged  - Theories of social stratification, social exclusion, marginalisation, social construction, social justice and empowerment  - Evolving societal attitudes toward socially disadvantaged in service delivery, legislation and policy  - Enhancing social and individual well-being of the socially disadvantaged groups  - Strategies to achieve individual and social empowerment of the socially disadvantaged groups  - Reviewing the strengths and limitations of different policy initiatives and social programs in helping the socially disadvantaged groups

title: Living with Grief: Understanding Death, Dying and Bereavement
description: (UGED1602 is double-coded with SOWK1130.) Death is not special. It happens every day and everywhere. It is also an inevitable part of life. Yet, death is very important for us especially when we are confronted by the death and dying of our loved ones. Surprisingly, we have done little to prepare ourselves to get familiar with the topic of bereavement. Very often we learn it only from the most painful and heartbreaking moments in life—after the death of loved ones. While bereavement may induce us different grief reactions, and adjustment difficulties, it also provides an opportunity for us to experience personal growth, reflect on our values and search for the meaning in life. As a result, this course aims to prepare students to face death, dying and bereavement that they may encounter in their life. In particular, they are facilitated to respond to a unique question, “How can I live with the grief?” This question can only be answered by the students themselves who will have an opportunity to understand more about death, dying and bereavement, as well as reflecting on their life and living through this course.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  Describe the common reactions and processes in dying and grieving;  Develop a developmental and contextual understanding on death, dying and bereavement;  Apply relevant knowledge to enhance adjustment to bereavement and live with grief; and  Reflect on their values, life priorities and meaning in life.
syllabus: 1. Basic knowledge on death and dying: a. concepts of good death, b. attitudes towards death, e.g. death anxiety, death acceptance c. the dying process, d. adjustment to anticipatory grief   2. Basic knowledge on bereavement, a. grief reactions b. grief processes and theories, e.g. Dual Process Model c. specific types of bereavement, e.g. suicidal bereavement, men’s grief, elderly grief, children’s grief, etc. d. adjustment bereavement, and living with grief   3. Values, life priorities and meaning in life a. Existential perspective on life, death and bereavement b. Search for meaning in life following bereavement (e.g. Vitkor Frankl’s logotherapeutic perspective)

title: Choices in Life: An Invitation to Self-Development
requirements: Not for students who have taken UGED2591, UGED1600, GESC2117, PSYC1030 or SOWK1113.
description: (UGED1600 is double-coded with SOWK1150.) This course adopts a humanistic approach to personal growth. It aims at facilitating students to achieve better self-understanding and self-confidence, expand options in life and develop greater self-acceptance. Through classroom instruction and small group experiential learning, students will be guided to review their personal growth and development, to examine issues and choices in significant aspects of their lives, and to reflect on their values and attitudes. Major topics covered include human development, family and relationships, love and sexuality, health and wellness, society and social responsibility, study and career, and death and loss.
outcome: By the end of the course, students are expected to:    1.      acquire basic understanding of major perspectives on human nature and development; 2.      appreciate the interaction between individual and the social environment in the course of self development; 3.      reflect on their current lifestyles and life goals, and contemplate on possible alternatives; 4.      examine and reflect on significant issues in young adulthood.

title: Movies, Life and Social Work
description: (UGED1651 is double-coded with SOWK1160.) This course is designed to examine human life issues through movie watching. A social work perspective and a humanistic outlook of life will be adopted to view human lives at individual, family and society levels. Students are expected to develop an awareness and a sense of concern for people and the society. Movies related to social work values, such as people's capacity for change, respect for human worth and dignity, and social justice will be reviewed and discussed. Social issues, such as discrimination, mental illness and issue of oppression will also be covered.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  Critically review and discuss on different social and life issues which are relevant to themselves and others as human beings;  Apply social work perspectives and values in analysing different social phenomena and life issues through film media;  Develop their point of views towards different issues with critical mind; and  Show care and concern towards the well-being of people in need.
syllabus: 1.   Introduction: Essence of social work practice; what can be offered by movies (entertainment, knowing about the world around, thought-inspiration) – how movies reflect on human lives and social conditions.  2.     Connecting to humanity in movies: The “Humanistic” view of human being –  a genuine concern for people’s lives  a high respect for human value  a loving heart for touching with human sufferings and people’s struggles, etc.  3.     The “Psychoanalytic” view of human being -  structure of personality, how it differs from the humanistic view   conscious & unconscious in relating to human behaviours  service gaps in working with people having mental health problems 4.   Today’s Youngsters: At the Crossroad – a) “Behavioural” view of human being; and b) ‘Cognitive-behavioural” view  the importance of environment in shaping behaviours of human    familial, social and personal issues faced by our young generations  youth service in Hong Kong 5.     Love Relationships  Essence of Love Affairs/Romantic Relationships  Common issues encountered by social workers, e.g. Extra-marital affairs 6.     Fight for justice  what is justice and injustice  standing for justice  social advocacy for justice  7.  Poverty  a big gap between the rich & the poor  social measures to reduce poverty 8.     Lonely elderly?  needs of elderly  to concern for the well-being of our elderly  elderly service in Hong Kong 9.     Treasure the Family  common issues in family  dealing with communication barriers 10.   Sexual discrimination in society  homosexuality as a social issue  our attitudes towards sexual orientation 11.  Getting Free from Stress & Anxiety/Take good care of our mental health  sources of stress  effects of stress  coping well with stress 12.  Life is what we make of it  how we perceive life and cope with human adversity  people can enjoy life when they encounter difficulties and hardships

title: Student-Orientated Teaching I
description: This is a small group, semi-structured teaching course which is related to the students' coursework learning, but not formally tied to any particular course. It aims to help students to examine the meaning of helping and to reflect on their views on social work as a helping profession. Students are encouraged to review their own values, attitudes and commitments as well as related issues in pursuing a career in the human services.Advisory: For Majors only.
outcome: At the end of the course, students are expected to:  1. Achieve understanding of the self and the family in relation to the society. 2. Apprehend the significance of self-understanding to helping and social work learning.  3. Enhance the capacity in social work learning via self-reflections, self-love and self-awareness. 4. Reflect the values and attitudes for pursuing a career in social work.
syllabus: 1. Understanding about myself, family and the influence of family on me 2. What is the meaning of help and helping attitude of a social worker 3. Relationship between the person and the environment in the changing contexts 4. Review on life goals, values and aptitudes in pursuing a career in social work

title: Philosophy and Principles of Social Work
description: This course aims to enable students to develop a basic understanding of social work. It will examine the nature and scope of social work practice and look into the philosophical base, value system and practice principles of the social work profession. Discussion will focus on emerging trends of social work, ethical dilemma in social work practice, as well as the application of social work values and principles in practice.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:    1. acquire an understanding of the meaning of social work and the scope of its practice;  2. examine the philosophical base and core values of social work;  3. develop an understanding of the ethical and practice principles which guide social work practice; and  4. identify with the humanistic values of the social work profession, including social justice and promotion of the welfare of its clientele.
syllabus: 1. Nature of Social Work  2. Philosophical Base and Core Values of Social Work  3. Ethical Issues and Decision-Making in Social Work Practice  4. Social Work Relationship  5. On Becoming a Social Worker

title: Interprofessional Learning for Social Work in Health Care
description: This course enables students to explore, in an interprofessional context, the social issues in the health care and understand the roles and functions of social work in health care system. A primary objective is to provide students with innovative, cross-disciplinary, team-based learning experience which involves medicine, nursing, pharmacy, public health and other health profession to develop knowledge, skills and attitudes related to competence in interprofessional collaboration, foster interprofessional teamwork in health care, and prepare them for careers across healthcare-relevant practice settings.

title: Service-learning Online Course
description: This online course aims to provide students with an overview of Service-Learning (S-L), including its definition, its relevant concepts and theories, and its implications for the good of society and enhancement of personal development. Through different online materials and interactive exercises, students can learn how to assess the needs of different communities, define objectives, design service projects creatively, implement the projects to meet these needs, and develop methods to evaluate the outcomes. Students will be encouraged to reflect on how the knowledge and skills that they have acquired in their own disciplines may facilitate the development of S-L projects. It is designed in the form of self-paced e-Learning modules which can be taken as a standalone prerequisite to students’ self-initiated service projects.
outcome: After completing this online course, students will be able to: Understand the concepts and value of S-L for the society and their personal development; Apply the skills of communicating with various vulnerable communities; Analyze the theories on assessing the needs of communities; Apply the concepts of designing, planning, implementing and evaluating innovative service projects meeting the needs of the targeted communities; and  Reflect and integrate S-L with knowledge and skills acquired in their own disciplines.

title: Human Behaviour and the Social Environment
requirements: Not for students who have taken SOWK1113 and PSYC2540.
description: This course aims to enable students to understand the basic concepts, theories, and problems in human growth and behaviour as related to social work practice. Emphasis is given to the study of human growth and behaviour across the life span within different socio-cultural contexts, including family, group, organization and community settings. Attention will be paid to physical, psychological and socio-cultural aspects of growth and the reciprocal interactions between individuals, families, groups, and the environment.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. develop a perspective in understanding on human behavior in social environment; 2. acqure knowledge on the basic concepts, theoretical perspectives and issues in human growth and development; 3. outline human growth and behavior throughout the stages from pregnancy to late adulthood and the end of life with reference to socio-cultural contexts; 4. recognize the reciprocal relationships between human behavior and social environments throughout the life course;  5. apply knowledge on social work practice in relation to developmental needs, risk and protective factors; and  6. reflect on the values and attitudes toward human development.
syllabus: 1. Study of human development 2. Human nature and theories 3. Prenatal development, birth, physical and cognitive development during the first three years 4. Psychosocial development during the first three years 5. Physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development in early childhood 6. Physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development in middle childhood 7. Physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development in adolescence 8. Physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development in young adulthood 9. Physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development in middle adulthood 10. Physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development in late adulthood 11. The end of life: death, dying and bereavement  12. Social work practice: understanding human behaviors in the social environment

title: Mental Disorders
requirements: Not for students who have taken PSYC3700.
description: This course aims to enable students to understand the various forms, classification, assessment, causes and management of mental disorders including mental illness and mental deficiency. Emphasis will also be put on the psychosocial impacts of mental disorders on individuals and families; and the roles of social worker in psychiatric rehabilitation and mental health services.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. adopt a biopsychosocial perspective in conceptualizing mental health and mental disorders;  2. contextualize mental health problems and mental disorders in Hong Kong; 3. acquire knowledge in the holistic management of mental disorders;  4. acquire knowledge in the promotion of mental health and prevention of mental disorders; and 5. identify and examine the significant roles and functions of social workers in mental health services in Hong Kong.
syllabus: Course Introduction: Concepts of mental health and mental disorders & Objectives of mental health practice in social work Psychopathology with existential perspective Recovery model and its application   Diagnosis and Mental Health Assessment  Case assessment and formulation Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders  Mood Disorder: Depressive Disorders   Mood Disorder: Bipolar and related Disorders   Mood Disorder: Anxiety and Panic Disorders   Mood Disorder: Obsessive-Compulsive and Hoarding Disorders    Mood Disorder: Personality Disorders  Mental Disorders for Childhood and Elderly Medicine, other modes of treatment and interprofessional communication

title: Economic Insecurity and Social Security in Global Contexts
description: (UGEC2631 is double-coded with SOWK2160.) This course aims at analyzing economic insecurity from a global perspective and introducing social security as a societal measure to combat economic insecurity. Specifically, this course will examine the sources of economic insecurity of the individual and the relationship between globalization and economic insecurity. It will also discuss the philosophy, development, characteristics and functions of different types of social security measures in different countries and analyze current debates on the future development of social security in national and cross-national perspective.
outcome: Upon the completion of this course, students should be able to: 1.        comprehend the meaning and nature of economic insecurity in globalized world; 2.        understand the extent of economic insecurity and poverty in Hong Kong and in other societies; 3.        acquire knowledge on social security as a societal measure to combat economic insecurity and poverty; 4.        become familiar with the political and economic contexts in the development of social security, national differences in the provision of economic security, major types of provisions and issues of social security; 5.        analyze contemporary debates regarding the philosophy and future direction of social security development in national and cross-national perspective.
syllabus: Insecurity and economic insecurity 1. Meaning and types of insecurity in the globalised world 2. Economic insecurity – definition, sources and impact 3. Economic and financial globalization and economic insecurity   Understanding global poverty 1. Concepts and definitions 2. Theories of poverty causation 3. Measuring poverty, poverty incidence and trends 4. Strategies to combat poverty and economic insecurity 5. Global overview of economic insecurity and poverty 6. Global goals, frameworks and strategies in eradicating poverty and economic insecurity   Social security: a strategy to combat poverty and economic insecurity 1. Concept, definitions, objectives and scope 2. Historical trends in social security development 3. Types and branches of social security provisions and their underpinning values and principles 4. Structural components of social security provisions 5. Welfare ideologies and social security systems 6. Global overview of social security practices 7. Development and provisions of social security in Hong Kong in comparison with other countries and jurisdictions – similarities and differences     Old age and economic insecurity 1. A global perspective on economic insecurity and poverty in old age 2. Measures to relieve economic insecurity and hardship in old age – options, strengths and weaknesses 3. Mandatory Provident Fund Vs. Old Age Pension Scheme 4. Balancing fiscal viability and financial security of old age   Unemployment, underemployment and economic insecurity 1. Unemployment & underemployment: global trends & regional characteristics 2. Economic insecurity associated with unemployment and underemployment 3. Measures to combat economic insecurity associated with unemployment and underemployment – social security, active labour market policies & community economic development – local and overseas 4.  The working poor   Economic insecurity arising from sickness; & Health Care 1. Economic insecurity associated with sickness and health risks 2. Access to affordable and sustainable health care – problems and options   Conclusion 1. Contributions, criticisms and issues of social security programs in combating economic insecurity and global poverty 2. Debates and controversies on future development of social security in national and cross-national perspective 3. Integration of social security and other public and social measures

title: Interpersonal Violence
description: (UGEC2680 is double-coded with SOWK2200.) The purposes of this course are to provide students a basic understanding of violence that takes place in our daily life in the contexts of intimate relationship, family, school and community and to arouse their consciousness of contemporary values of equality, human rights and social justice. Various concepts and theories of violence will be introduced to explore the nature, causes, consequences and trends of violence in different aspects of life. Emphasis will be placed on the issues of interpersonal violence in contemporary societies. Social policy and provisions to prevent and eliminate interpersonal violence will also be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:1.      Critically examine the contemporary perspectives, concepts and theories on interpersonal violence.2.    Analyze causes and consequences of interpersonal violence in different contexts.3.      Apply and integrate interdisciplinary theories of violence to evaluate current policy and strategies on tackling violence.4.      Reflect on ways to combat violence and help to promote a peaceful environment.5.      Appreciate the contemporary values of equality, human rights and social justice.
syllabus: 1.      Common misunderstanding and myths of interpersonal violence.2.      Contemporary perspectives and theories of violence from anthropology, education, medical science, politics, psychology, sociology and social work.3.      Nature, causes, consequences and trends of interpersonal violence.4.      The needs of victims and perpetrators of interpersonal violence.5.      Risk and protective factors of violence at personal, family, school, community and policy levels.6.      Issues of violence in regard to different genders, ages, classes, sexual orientations and cultures.7.      Current social policy and prevention programs on interpersonal violence.

title: Social Work and Cultural Diversity
description: (UGEC2684 is double-coded with SOWK2202.)  This course provides students with fundamental and systematic knowledge on issues related to ethnic and cultural diversity. Apart from introducing contemporary theories and conceptual perspectives about cultural sensitivity and cultural intelligence, this course will also highlight major discourses and challenges concerning access, equity, social inclusiveness, cultural assimilation and integration which have substantial impact on ethnic minorities as well as social harmony. Through participation in small group projects, guided community tours, and face-to-face interaction with different ethnic groups, students will be able to develop an awareness of the differences in values, beliefs, life-style and interpersonal relatedness between themselves and people of other ethnic background. Basic skills, knowledge and attitude required of cultural intelligence, equal-opportunity legislations, social policies, service provision in meeting the needs of ethnic minorities, and measures to promote mutual acceptance and social inclusiveness will be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1.            Acquire knowledge of the key concepts and theoretical perspectives of multiculturalism, related social policies and service delivery system; 2.            Apply an intercultural perspective to understand the struggles, challenges and socio-cultural barriers of ethnic groups in Hong Kong. 3.            Evaluate the impact of culture on individuals and/or groups’ values, beliefs, behaviours, attitudes, preferences and life pursuits; 4.            Develop awareness in cultural sensitivity and acquire cultural competence as well as intercultural intelligence
syllabus: 1.       Background and global trend of cultural diversity a.      Globalization and Ethnic Diversity b.      Culture, Ethnicity and Diversity c.       Impacts of culture on economy, health, education, immigration, social service, community development, public policy and social harmony 2.       Major perspectives in cultural diversity and Intercultural Intelligence a.       “Person-in-environment” Perspective b.      Multi-culturalism c.       The Intercultural Perspective 3.       Understanding ethnic and culture groups in Hong Kong a.       Major Ethnic and Cultural Groups in Hong Kong b.      Cultural Barriers and Dilemmas faced by members of ethnic minority groups c.       Stress, vulnerability, strengths and resilience in ethnic and migrant groups d.      Access and Equity 4.       Cross-culture assessment and cultural formation 5.       Development of cultural sensitivity, cultural competence and intercultural intelligence

title: Mission-driven Social Enterprise
description: (UGEC2693 is double-coded with SOWK2203.) This course introduces to students the field of mission-driven social enterprise, which aims to achieve a balance between meaningful social returns as well as sustainable or competitive financial returns through their products, services and other business practices. Through examining the best practices in social entrepreneurship, it also stimulates students to explore how social enterprise can affect policy and facilitate system change. Experiential learning elements such as visiting social enterprises and having dialogue with social entrepreneurs, staff members or service users will be arranged in order to let students experience its operation, understand its practice as well as to enable students in realizing its possibilities in offering solutions to education, healthcare, environment, workforce development, international development and other societal issues. The course is valuable to students who may want to design or lead a mission-driven social enterprise, or want to contribute time and energy to help build the social sector through this emerging field.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to ·         Understand how social entrepreneurs work to blend disparate goals, how and why social enterprises successfully fuse purpose and personal passion in business, and how visions and values are embedded in organizational culture; ·         Be familiar with a variety of approaches and tools to measure organizational performance and social impact of social enterprise. ·         Examine the key methods, strategies and models for social enterprises to succeed; ·         Understand the dimensions and models of social entrepreneurship and the strategies on fundraising, financial management, opportunity seeking, social marketing, alliance building, etc. ·         Apprehend how social enterprises leverage their work and impact to influence policy and the community; Critically evaluate how social enterprise can fulfil the objectives of meeting economic, ecological and social needs.

title: Social Innovation and Social Change for Good
description: (UGEC2686 is double-coded with SOWK2204.)  This course prepares students to learn from the emerging practices of social innovations in tackling with challenges in social, economic, cultural and political development in Hong Kong, the Greater China region and beyond. Students will acquire analysis, knowledge and strategies of social innovations, the processes of social change in creating social values. The scope of social innovations includes that of social entrepreneurs or social innovators in NGOs, communities, social movements, non-profit organizations, and business as well as the public sector. The course will examine cases of social innovations that have catalyzed important positive social change through the market, the nonprofit sector, the community, the public sector as well as the spaces among those four sectors. Experiential learning will be integrated along the course delivery, such as programmme visits, dialogue with social entrepreneurs, staff members or service users. Students are encouraged to experience these operations, so as to analyze the development issues, the social values and innovations in offering practical solutions to poverty and social inequalities, unemployment and livelihood, civic and community engagement, fair trade as well as sustainable development. The course will provide inspirations as well as know-hows for students who are concerned about the articulation of local with global and regional issues and like to develop innovative actions to change the society for good.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to ·         Realise how social innovations work to target social issues, creating social values through innovative strategies in various sectors as well as cross sectoral collaboration; ·         Recognize the basic know-hows of social innovation such as design thinking, community or civic engagement, collaboration, prototyping and lean start-up; ·         Apprehend how social innovation leverage their work and impact to catalyze changes in the broader community, economy or political sphere. ·         Critically evaluate how social innovation can fulfil the objectives of coping with the challenges in the social, economic, cultural and political spheres. ·         Acquire personal experience and prepare to taking own responsibilities as global citizen and ready to be social innovator / social entrepreneur in tackling the local, regional and global development challenges.

title: Social Casework
description: This course aims to help students acquire an understanding of the nature, principles and application of social casework. The values, knowledge and skills essential to casework intervention with individuals and families will be introduced with reference to the generalist model and the psychosocial approach. Emphasis will be put on the interplay between stressful life events, social environment, clients' individual functioning as well as their interpersonal relationships.Advisory: For Majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:   1. understand the nature, principles and knowledge base of social casework;  2. develop a conceptual understanding of the psycho-social perspective in social work intervention;  3. examine social work values underpinning practice;  4. comprehend the core conditions of the helping process;  5. understand the diverse nature of social work roles and enhance the conscious use of self in the helping process;  6. master skills essential to casework intervention; 7. examine the current social casework practice in Hong Kong; and  8. increase sensitivity towards cultural and human diversity, and understand its importance in casework intervention.
syllabus: 1. Nature of social casework 2. Experience of becoming a client and stage of change 3. Theoretical perspectives (Ecological perspective & Strengths perspective) 4. Practice models (Psychosocial Approach & Generalist model) 5. Social caseworker’s role 6. The helping process-Engagement and alliance building 7. The helping process- Exploration and Assessment 8. The helping process- Goal setting and planning 9. The helping process- Action 10. Crisis intervention Case Management 11. The helping process- Evaluation & Termination 12. Issues confronting beginning caseworkers 13. Review & Conclusion

title: Social Group Work
description: The course aims at providing students with a basic understanding of the knowledge and skills of social group work. Major models and techniques of group intervention will be introduced. Attention will be given to the roles of the group worker and his/her purposeful use of group process and programmes.Advisory: For Majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. understand the nature, principles and knowledge base of social group work;  2. identify various stages of group development, and the roles of a social worker in respective stage;  3. understand the different conceptual models in social group work practice;  4. familiarize with group dynamics, and understand how they can be used to achieve the social work objectives; 5. appreciate the application of the group work method in working with different clientele groups; and  6. plan for a group and review group achieve.
syllabus: 1. An overview on social group work 2. Knowledge base, values and principles of social group work 3. Conceptual models in social group work 4. Stages of group development 5. Pre-group planning and group formation 6. Basic group work skills  7. Group dynamics in the beginning, transitional, working and ending phases of a group  8. Evaluation of group achievement  9. Application of social group work in Chinese community to work with different clientele groups

title: Community Work
description: This course aims to provide students with the basic knowledge and skills of community work. It will examine the basic concepts, theoretical assumptions, values and skills of community work. Modes of intervention in different settings and current debates and challenges in community practice will also be examined.Advisory: For Majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. understand the nature, principles and knowledge base of community work: include the concept of empowerment and strength perspective. 2. identify various stages of community work intervention, and the roles of a social worker in respective stages; 3. understand the different conceptual models in community work practice, and apply these models in intervention planning; 4. familiarize with community dynamics, and understand how they can be used to achieve macro social work objectives; 5. appreciate the application of community work method in working with geographical and functional communities; and 6. plan a community work intervention and review its achievement.
syllabus: 1. What is Community & Community Work? 2. Principle and values of community work 3. History and current situation of community work in Hong Kong 4. Skills of Community Work  5. Community work intervention models (II): Advocacy and Social Action 10. Community work intervention models (III): Community Care 11. Future and Prospect of Community Work

title: Social Work Field Laboratory
description: This course adopts a laboratory training format to provide students with opportunities to experience and become familiar with events encountered in the field. outcome: It is hoped that through experiential encounters in laboratory drilling at the end of the course, the students are able to:           1.    Reflect upon the helping attitude so as to achieve self understanding and personal growth;2.    Develop sensitivity in working with people;3.    Develop communication skills in working with individual, groups and communities;4.    Develop the ability to use social work knowledge to solve problems encountered in field practice; and5.    Reflect on social work values in field practice.

title: Clinical Social Work Theories and Practice
description: This course aims to help students acquire knowledge and skills in clinical social work practice. Specifically, it attempts to familiarize students with current major approaches in working with individuals, families and groups and help students develop an integrative perspective in direct practice.Advisory: For Majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:   1. gain an understanding of the theoretical framework and principles of some selected practice theories and approaches in working with individuals, families and groups;  2. acquire an ability to select and make use of practice theories to guide the assessment of the strengths, needs, problems and the social context of target clients;  3. develop an ability to systematically formulate intervention goals, treatment plans and intervention strategies in working with different types of client systems;  4. identify and examine ethical issues in current clinical social work practice, and 5. critically reflect on their own values and roles in the helping process.
syllabus: I. Introduction and basic issues in clinical social work ． The basic philosophy in clinical social work ． Relationship between theory, social work practice and research  ． The personhood of worker and the therapeutic process  II. Clinical social work theories and practice ． Person-centered therapy ． Cognitive therapy ． Behavioral therapy and SSLD (Skills, Strategies, Learning and Development) ． Psychodynamic therapy ． Gestalt therapy  III. Special issues and summing up  ． Ethical issues in clinical social work practice ． Cultural issues in clinical social work practice

title: Macro Social Work Theories and Practice
description: Macro social work is a blend of social awareness, welfare practice reflection and organizing skills. The course aims to equip students with the basic knowledge and skills in performing the above functions through examining relevant macro social work theories and approaches. Emphasis will be put on the changing practice context for macro practice, service integration, community organizing and networking, and how the welfare of the vulnerable group within the larger society can be promoted.Advisory: For Majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the students will be able to  1. apply knowledge and skills in performing macro social work practice; 2. have a basic understanding of the main social policy issues (poverty, social development) in Hong Kong that affect the welfare conditions of the people in general and the disadvantaged groups in particular; and 3. understand and apply strategies, skills, and determinants of policy advocacy.
syllabus: 1. Overview of Macro Social Work and Macro social work values: equality, social justice, human rights, liberty, freedom (autonomy, self-determination), participation 2. Theories of Macro Social Work (I): from neoliberalism to Marxism 3. Theories of Macro Social Work (II): post-structuralist macro social work 4. Gender sensitive practice – changing women, changing men 5. Anti-racist social work 6. Globalisation and International Social Work  7. Social Development and Green Social Work 8. Macro social work and new social movement 9. The Future of Macro Social Work

title: Social Welfare Administration
description: This course aims to provide students with the basic knowledge of social welfare agency administration. Basic management theories, principles and methods in administration, service planning, administrative structure and operation, personnel and financial management, and evaluation of social welfare agencies will be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:   1. describe the nature and characteristics of welfare organizations, and articulate their implication to social welfare administration;  2. recognize the various management functions and tasks in welfare organizations;  3. recognize and understand the range of management and organizational theories relating to the management of welfare organizations; 4. apply management and organizational theories to analyze key issues and challenges in managing welfare organizations in Hong Kong; and 5. develop initiatives and change strategies to manage crisis and challenges confronting local welfare organizations.

Features and characteristics of human service organizations & value and ethics in welfare service management4. Management v.s. managerialism  5. Accountability  6. Program planning  7. Performance monitoring  8. Quality management  9. Program evaluation  10. Managing resources  11. Participatory management

title: Social Work Research
description: This course is designed to provide students with an understanding of the nature, concepts and principles of social work research. The research process, including problem formulation, research design, data collection and analysis, and presentation of findings will be examined. Students are expected to be able to conduct social work research and make effective use of research findings.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:   1. acquire basic knowledge of quantitative and qualitative social work research methods; 2. understand how social work research methods apply to social work practice and promote social justice; 3. conduct qualitative or/and quantitative research methods at undergraduate level; and  4. critically appraise current social work research studies.

title: Social Policy and Planning
description: This course aims to facilitate student’s understanding of the contribution of social planning and policy formulation to the solution, control or amelioration of social problems on the macro-level. A knowledge of the key elements of decision-making; an understanding of what is involved when designing social service programmes consistent with the economic capacity, cultural values and standards of modern societies, such as Hong Kong will be introduced.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. master the basic theoretical ideas, ethical considerations and practical context relevant to social policy in modern society;  2. understand the essential policies relevant to the general welfare of people, the vulnerable groups in particular;  3. examine key elements of decision making in policy fomulation and social service program development;  4. acquire basic skills of collecting, analysing and evaluating secondary data, including government official documents and statistics; and  5. critically evaluate policy literature in relation to the theoretical arguments.

title: Field Instruction I
requirements: Prerequisites: SOWK2020, 2210, 2220, 2230 and 2430
description: The course provides opportunities for students to put theories learnt in class into practice in an agency setting and under supervision. Students are expected to apply : (a) methods of direct service to clients – casework, group work and community organization; (b) knowledge and use of community resources; (c) tasks akin to agency administration – planning, budgeting, staffing, etc., and (d) tools for administration – writing of reports, letters, accounting, use of research findings, conducting meetings, etc.Advisory: For Majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are able to:   1. Demonstrate good knowledge and understanding of factors influencing the service development and social work practice in the placement agency and the service setting; 2. Identify with and apply social work values, assumptions and principles in practice; 3. Self-examine and reflect on learning and practice experience; 4. Make good use of social science knowledge in understanding and analysing human behaviour in social environment; and 5. Apply basic helping skills in different stages of social work interventions.
syllabus: 1. Familiarizing with the community: agency and community visits  2. Learning needs identification and selection of assignments  3. Formulating case assessment reports, group and/or project proposals  4. Implementing case/group/project 5. Evaluation on case/group/project 6. Reflecting on self as social worker
required_readings: Readings are assigned by individual field instructors according to different service natures of different placement units.

title: Student Orientated Teaching II
description: This is a capstone course for students to integrate their learning in various aspects in social work and prepare themselves for the future career in social work. The course is a small group teaching course designed for final year students. It aims to help students reflect on and apply the values, knowledge, and skills of social work practice. Students are required to take initiative in their own learning through library research, critical examination of relevant materials, intellectual exchange of ideas, and sharing of personal experiences.Advisory: For Majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. analyze the needs and characteristics of the clientele they served;  2. examine the interactions between the client system and factors at micro, meso, and macro levels;  3. apply social work theories or practice models to guide the formulation of intervention goals and strategies;  4. integrate the values, knowledge, and skills of social work practice; and  5. develop a positive attitude and stronger identification with the social work profession.
syllabus: 1. Introduction and overview 2. Review on meaningful and significant experience in practicum  3. Need assessment and clientele identification of the project 4. Literature review on target clientele and knowledge concerned 5. Conceptualization and intervention 6. Conculsion and consolidation of learning
required_readings: Reference materials in previous course, library search for relevant literature, local documents, as well as reference materials in field practicum can be used for the preparation of the presentation and the individual project paper.

title: Social Work Guided Research
description: This is an advanced capstone course for students to integrate their learning in various aspects in Social Work. Students will have to plan and conduct a guided research on an approved topic on local or overseas welfare system and practice, and write a project report under the supervision and guidance of a faculty member with relevant specialty.(Advisory: For major students with CGPA of not lower than 3.3 only)
outcome: Upon completion of the courses, students would be able to:  (1) Understand the role of social work in contributing to the progress of local and global welfare systems; (2) Apply social work concepts and theories independently in social work research; (3) Master basic qualitative and quantitative research methods in social work; (4) Develop awareness and understanding about policy and practice of social work in a global context.

title: Global Justice, International Order and Policy Building
description: Globalization not only brings significant impact on economic development but also significantly redefines norms and values. From the Universal Declaration of Human Rights being ratified in 1949 to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development Goals adopted in 2015, international mechanisms, such as the United Nations, have constantly constructed social values under prerequisite global power order among nations. Globalization shapes international value and policy setting, political power among nation states and intergovernmental organizations influences local policy environment that goes beyond the regulation of nation state. This course offers an opportunity for the students to understand three levels of human rights development: ideology, political interplay, and policy formulation. Through exploring the causes and constructions of human rights, this course sets the grounds for students to comprehend knowledge on the current human rights and policy debates concerning social citizenship in relations to the underlying process of the international mechanisms and power relationships. Judging from the debates, students will also explore and analyze globalization and the regional impact on a variety of actors in social policy and on local policymaking.

title: Employment, Labour, Poverty and Social Policy
description: The course aims to help students understand the current labour and employment issues in Hong Kong and other contemporary societies internationally. Special attention will be given to economic insecurity and unemployment issues and how these issues inter-related to the issues of poverty. Different service provision and strategy of the governments will be reviewed, and current debates on the philosophy and the future direction of labour and employment services will be analyzed.

title: Law and Social Work
description: This course aims to introduce students to an understanding of the Basic Law, the legal system, court proceedings and laws relevant to matrimony, criminal justice and social welfare in Hong Kong. Students are expected to apply the relevant legal knowledge to different social work settings, and be able to review roles of social work in the legal systems.
outcome: This course aims to equip the students with essential legal knowledge and professional attitudes so that they can project the risk, protect the vulnerable clients and prevent the tragedy and as far as possible with the necessary legal measures:  equipping themselves with knowledge about the legal and judicial systems of Hong Kong, an important structure to social work practice;   developing professional and fair attitude towards social advocacy and social responsibilities, which are the crucial professional attitudes and visions when helping the vulnerable people ;  acquiring knowledge and skills in statutory and legal requirements for risk assessment and risk management for effective and fair social work practice; and   contextualizing the dilemma in practicing law and contemporary philosophy and principles of social work.

Family Law:  -Child Custody & Ancillary Relief -Domestic and Cohabitation Relationship  -Violence Ordinance and Spouse/Cohabitant Battering 5. Law for Protection of Children and Juveniles : -PCJO and Child Welfare (guardianship, wardship, adoption and child abuse) 6. Mental Health Law :  -compulsory admission, conditional discharge and community rehabilitation -guardianship 7. HK Employment Law  8. Anti-Discrimination Laws  9. Judicial Review  10. Application of legal knowledge in Social Work Practice : Case Discussion  11. Revision, Report drafting in court procedures & Roles and Responsibilities of Social Workers

title: Seminar I: Family-centered Social Work
description: This course aims to provide students with an integrative and family-centered framework in working with families and individuals. Focus is given to the understanding of family-centered practice as a holistic approach that integrates the various social work methods in the helping process. In line with the social work values, it is based on the beliefs and practices that treat families with dignity and respect. Guided with these beliefs and principles, the changing family ideologies, policies on family, the adequacy of family services in Hong Kong and the formulation of an integrative and family centered service delivery system will be critically examined.Advisory: For majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. understand what family-centered practice is; 2. acquire an eco-systemic-constructionist perspective in understanding and helping families and individual family members; 3. critically examine the relationship of the changing social context, family ideologies, policies on family and the needs of families in Hong Kong; and 4. apply the knowledge and principles of family-centered practice in needs assessment and service design.
syllabus: 1: What is Family-centered Practice? 2: Basic Beliefs, Theoretical Base and Principles of Family-centered Practice  3: Interventions and services in Family-Centered Practice 4: Family-Centered Practice with Post-Divorce Families  5: Family Centered Practice in Psychiatric Rehabilitation Services  6: Family-Centered Practice in Rehabilitation Services  7: Family-Centered Practice in Residential Child Care Services  8: Implementation of Family-centered Social Work Practice in Different Service Settings

title: Seminar II: Social Work with Young People
description: This course aims to provide students with an in-depth understanding of social work practice with young people. Apart from familiarizing students with the philosophies, historical development and operational structures of youth services in Hong Kong, emphasis is placed on studying the needs and characteristics of local young people, as well as the major concepts, theories and interventional methods when working with young people and their families. Current policy issues related to welfare and rights of young people will also be discussed.Advisory: For Majors only.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. understand the needs and characteristics of young people in Hong Kong; 2. examine the historical development, objectives, and present operation of local youth services; 3. become familiar with the major youth social work approaches and practices in Hong Kong; 4. use social science theories to analyze current youth issues; 5. explore the life concerns and stories of young people and know how this exploration can help guide their intervention goals and actions; and 6. equip themselves with practical skills in empowering young people.
syllabus: 1. Understanding the concepts of youth and youth-at-risk;  2. A profile of youth in Hong Kong and its implications for youth policy and practice  3. Theoretical foundations of the matrix model to understanding youth   4. Understanding the major youth social work approaches and practices • The historical development of youth services in Hong Kong • Current youth social work practices in Hong Kong • Major youth social work approaches  5. The helping relationship, process and skills in social work with young people   6. Career Development- self journey  7. A strengthen approach to youth work  8. Contentious issues in youth work  • Self-harm and suicide, mental health • Substance abuse • Social withdrawal • Juvenile delinquency • Teenage sexuality & pregnancy • Bullying and victim  9. Use of art in youth work practice   10. Youth social work in transition: Opportunities and challenges in times of rapid sociopolitical transformation

title: Seminar III: Social Work with Older People
description: This course aims to equip students with a systematic, humanistic, and integrative perspective when working with older people in interdisciplinary settings. Apart from providing students with information on the psychosocial, mental, economic, and health conditions of older people, this course introduces to students some major gerontological theories, policies and services (e.g. home-based services, community-based services, long-term care services and financial aids), with a focus on empowering older people. Also, current policy issues related to the advancement of betterment of older people will be critically examined and discussed.Advisory: For Majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  1. acquire knowledge about the cultural, demographic, social, psychological, economic, and health status of the elderly in Hong Kong; 2. understand major sociological and psychological theories; 3. be equipped with social work professional values, ethics, and intervention methods with the elderly and their families; and 4. critically examine the adequacy of local elderly services and current policy issues for the elderly.
syllabus: 1. Conceptual definitions in the study of aging 2. Ageism - Prejudices and biases against aging and older persons 3. Major gerontological theories 4. Understand the process of aging from a biopsychosocial perspective 5. Aging population and its impact on society 6. Care Plan and Continuum of Care 7. Dying and Death in Old Age 8. Elder abuse & Depression and suicide in older adults 9. Employment, reemployment and social security issues for older adults 10. Impact of aging on family, Caregiving and caregiver burden, and Social support services to caregiver 11. Gerontechnology 12. Residential Care Homes - Challenges & Future Development 13. Cognitive issues and Dementia 14. Active and successful aging

title: Seminar IV: Social Work with People with Special Needs
description: This course aims to help students understand the psychological as well as the socio-political aspects of people with special needs. The course addresses the social construction of disability and discusses major concepts and critical issues relevant to service design in a contemporary context, with a view to creating an enabling environment for persons with special needs. Students are also expected to familiarize themselves with related policies and services in Hong Kong, and be able to make critical appraisals on the extent to which current social work services meet the needs of persons with special needs.Advisory: For Majors only.

title: Seminar V: Poverty and Social Exclusion
description: This course aims to examine the poverty and social exclusion problems from both a local and a global context. Theories of human capital, social capital, social exclusion, and globalization will be introduced to understand the causes and impacts of poverty and social exclusion. Upon completion of the course, students are expected to apply relevant theories in the analysis and practice to alleviate the poverty and social exclusion situations of different vulnerable populations, for example welfare recipients, women, working poor and ethnic minorities. Recent trends and issues on poverty and poverty alleviation will be discussed in the social context of Hong Kong and the changing regional and global environment.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:   1. develop an understanding of meaning and nature of poverty and its relation to social exclusion in contemporary societies;  2. examine the issues of poverty and social exclusion in selected societies, i.e. Hong Kong, China and UK;  3. review different alleviation strategies in combat poverty and social exclusion;  4. understand the current provisions of poverty alleviation programs and anti-social exclusion strategies with reference to the political and economic context of Hong Kong;  5. critically evaluate different poverty alleviation and anti-social exclusion policies, approaches, program and projects in Hong Kong and other countries; and  6. examine the roles of social workers in organizing and implementing poverty alleviating and ending social exclusion projects.
syllabus: 1)    Impact of globalization and regionalization on economic insecurity 2)    Poverty situations in Hong Kong, China and other developing countries under globalization3)    Concepts & Measurement of Poverty4)    Concept of social exclusion and anti-social exclusion policies and programmes5)    Poverty alleviation strategies I: Education & human capital investment6)    Poverty alleviation strategies II: Building social capital7)    Poverty alleviation strategies III: Work First – job creation, job subsidy and workfare8)    Poverty alleviation strategies IV: Social security and Minimum Wage9)    Evaluation of different poverty alleviation and anti-social exclusion policies, programmes and projects in Hong Kong

title: Seminar VII: Art-based Social Work Practice
description: This course combines the concepts of expressive arts in healing and basic working principles of arts-based social work practice. It is not creative arts therapy training, but exploring the resources of expressive arts for facilitating social work practice. The course is designed for social work students who are interested in learning the application of arts in counseling, group, and community work. It is also appropriate for those wishing to awake the seeds of creativity and make use of their inner resources for both personal growth and professional development. Expressive arts are powerful verbal, nonverbal, and imaginative tools for self-expression and communication. This arts-based social work practice is action-oriented and process-focused. Students have an opportunity to experiment the use of arts for creative exploration and self-understanding so that they can synthesize their personal experience with conceptual learning.Advisory: For majors only
outcome: Upon the completion of this course, students are expected to be able to  I. Knowledge: a. Understand what is arts-based social work practice; b. Acquire a Person-centered approach in using arts for empowerment.  II. Values: a. Apply arts in accordance with social work values and code of ethics; b. Demonstrate an ability to respect the boundaries of the helping relationship and other professionals/therapists.  III. Skills: a. Provide a safe, supportive and non-judgmental environment to apply arts for empowerment; b. Develop practical skills and sensitivity to apply arts in social work practice.
syllabus: 1. Course introduction- course objectives/program content/course requirements 2. Healing power/resources of arts- means of communication- dialogue between conscious & unconscious- container for emotions/ instincts- avenue for insights- transforming process of personal growth 3. Media Exploration- Therapeutic effects of different art modalities- Creative exploration- Art facilitation 4. Theoretical foundations of using creative arts for healing, health, and well-being- Psychoanalytical- Psychodynamic- Humanistic- Contemporary 5. Self-understanding through mask-making- Functions & Techniques of mask- making and self-exploration 6. Introduction to Music Therapy 7. Application of creative arts in social work practice- Individual counseling- Group work- Community setting 8. Outcome Measurement and Evaluation Measures- Research approaches and methods- Practice outcome- Case studies 9. Closure and Ending- Consolidation and termination- Techniques of leading the last session 10. Professional Pathway: Training & Supervision

title: Seminar VIII: Gender and Sexuality in Social Work Practice
description: Through examining the situations of women and people of diverse gender identities in local and global contexts, this seminar course aims to develop students’ interest and understanding towards different trending gender issues and integrating these issues in social welfare policymaking and social work practices. Critical concepts in social work, such as social justice, equality, power and empowerment, would be re-examined and analysed under various gender discourses. Students would then acquire skills and knowledge on assessing social policy and social work practices from a gender perspective, and be able to integrate global gender debates in local policy agenda and social work practices.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students are expected to be able to: Review and understand the position of women and people of various gender identities in local and global contexts; Analyze gender power dynamics and oppression; Examine current social policies and social work practices in addressing gender equality, oppression and discrimination; Develop knowledge and skillsets on anti-oppressive, anti-racist practices.

title: Seminar IX: Family Therapy
description: This course aims to help students understand the basic assumption and theoretical foundation of family therapy. The values, knowledge and skills essential to family practice will be introduced with a systemic perspective. Focus will be set on familiarizing students with the major approaches in working with families and the application of family therapy in different settings and with various target populations.Advisory: For Majors only.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:   1. grasp the basic assumptions and theoretical foundation of family therapy;  2. acquire a systems perspective in family practice; 3. get hold of the values and principles of family practice; 4. familiarize with the major family therapy approaches; 5. equip with knowledge and skills in family assessment and family intervention;  6. develop ability in applying family therapy in different settings and with various target populations; 7. understand the importance of family research and evidence-based practice within a human context; and 8. integrate gender and cultural perspectives in family practice.
syllabus: 1. Origins and evolution of family therapy 2. Fundamental concepts of family therapy 3. Classic schools of family therapy • Satir family therapy • Bowen family systems therapy • Structural family therapy • Strategic family therapy  4. Contemporary developments in family therapy • Postmodernism and social construction • Solution-focused family therapy • Narrative therapy  5. Assessment and engagement 6. Working with children 7. Working with adolescents 8. Working with couples

title: Family in Changing Society
requirements: For students in MA Family Counselling & Family Education, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare
description: This course examines different theories in conceptualizing families such as structural-functionalism, systems theory and the post-modernist’s view. The recent changes in family life in Hong Kong and in Chinese society connected to the changing socioeco- cultural context will be investigated. Particular attention will be given to the developmental needs and problems of families as well as the stress, coping and resilience of families in different stages. Culture and gender issues, the roles of social services and educational system, current problems and challenges confronting family development in Hong Kong will also be scrutinized.
outcome: Upon the completion of the course, the students are expected to be able to :1. Understand the changing conceptualizations of family, family normality and family pathology by examining different family theories.2. Know the recent changes in family life and family forms in Hong Kong and other Chinese societies connected to the changing socio-cultural context.3. Apply the theories in examining the implications of the social changes on individual and family well-beings. 4. Make critical reflection on the gender, class and cultural issues, the role of social services and educational system, current problems and challenges confronting family development in Hong Kong.
syllabus: Part I: Different Theories in Conceptualizing Families• Structural Functionalism• Family-Systems Theory and Family Development Theory• Social Constructionism • Feminism• What is “family” in traditional Chinese culture?Part II: Recent Changes in Family Life in Hong Kong and Other Chinese-Societies (selective topics for lectures and student presentations) • Divorce evolution and post-divorce family relationships• Work and Family Interface in Hong Kong• Global householding and cross-border living families• The changing meanings and patterns of intimate relationships in Hong Kong : Marriage, cohabitation and singlehood • The changing meanings and patterns of parenthood, childhood and grandparenthood in Hong Kong • Technology advancement and family life• Debates on the marriage rights and family rights of LGBTI • Negotiation of family relationships in a politically divisive social context

title: Theories and Practice of Family Counselling
requirements: For students in MA Family Counselling & Family Education, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare
description: This course aims to help students understand the basic assumption and theoretical foundation of family counselling and to help students acquiring a systemic perspective. The assumptions and rationales underlying major family counselling approaches such as structural and strategic family therapy, solution-focused therapy and narrative therapy will be discussed. Focuses will be lay on the application of family counselling in different social contexts, such as social service organizations, schools, hospitals, maternal and child health care centres.
outcome: Upon the completion of the course, the students are expected to be able to:1. Understand the theoretical foundation, basic concepts and skills of the approaches in family counseling that have been taught in the course.2. Understand the applicability of different perspectives in family counseling in the socio-cultural context of Hong Kong.3. Acquire an enhanced sensitivity on cultural and ethical issues in the actual practice.
syllabus: - Ethical decision making in family counselling and therapy- History and development of family therapy- Classical models of family therapy- Postmodernist models of family therapy- A common factors approach in family therapy

title: Theories and Practice of Family Education
requirements: For students in MA Family Counselling & Family Education, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare
description: This course examines the assumption and theoretical foundation of family education. It aims to help students understand different perspectives in family education and its implications for practice. Theories and concepts of parenting, adult learning and parenthood will be examined. Practical skills of assessing family and parental needs, curriculum and programme designs, and strategies in advocacy of family and parent education programmes will also be tackled. Focuses will be lay on the application of family education in different social contexts, such as social service organizations, schools, hospitals, maternal and child health care centres.
outcome: Students who have completed this course are expected to have further understanding and mastery of: 1. basic assumptions, approaches, theoretical foundations and conceptual frameworks in family education; 2. professional skills in analyzing human behaviours and needs of participants in conducting family education; 3. critical thinking in reviewing and assessing family education programmes; and 4. using cultural perspective in development and evaluation of family education programmes.
syllabus: - Introduction to family education - Cultural perspectives on family education - Approaches on family education : Transmission perspective - Approaches on family education: Transaction perspective - Approaches on family education : Transformation perspective - Models of couple education - Body, Sexuality and family education - Applications of family education - Emotionality and family education - Applications of family education - Conclusion: Critical reflections and future development

title: Fundamental Theories of Social Policy
requirements: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme, MA Programme in Social Policy and MA Programme in Social Service Management.
description: This course aims to enable students to have an understanding of basic concepts and theories in social policy. The content of the course focuses on basic ideas and theories of different social policy approaches e.g., human needs and rights, social exclusion, social development, and social quality. In emphasizing the theories of social policy and social welfare, the course is to enable students to have solid basic social policy understanding with reference to international experiences and value systems. Students will be facilitated to develop social policy understanding and capabilities of critical analysis.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:1) Understand different theories and frameworks of social policy and welfare provision.2) Critically and conceptually analyze current social welfare policies, procedures, and programs.3) Describe and critically analyze major fields of social welfare provision from a global and context-sensitive perspective.4) Discuss and critically analyze current policy debates, trends, and ethical issues in specific fields of welfare provision presented in the course including the implications for social work practice and promoting social justice and social change.
syllabus: - Theories of social policy and social welfare - Human needs and rights - Social exclusion; social development; and social quality

title: Social Policy and Social Welfare in China
requirements: For students in MA in Social Policy, MA in Social Service Management, MSSc in Social Work, Master of Social Work and MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare
description: This course introduces the development of social welfare policy in China. The relationship between social welfare policy and changing ideology, the differences in social welfare policy between urban and rural areas, and specific fields of social welfare policy in China, including social assistance policy, social insurance policy, employment policy, education policy, medical health care policy, housing policy, and social policies related to children, elders and disabled persons will be examined.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:  • Develop a holistic perspective to understand the social development and social welfare of contemporary China in a historical and global context; • Recognize the historical, economic, social, cultural and political factors that shape the social welfare system of contemporary China; • Become familiar with the pressing social issues in contemporary China, such as poverty, migration, healthcare, etc., as well as the policy responses to these social issues; • Become familiar with the social welfare system of contemporary China and its underlying ideological and theoretical base; • Develop the skills of critical thinking and analysis while evaluating the social welfare policies in China; • Apply the knowledge and skills learnt from class to examine China’s social welfare policy in particular dimensions as well as to provide reasonable recommendations for policy change.
syllabus: Part I: Globalisation, Welfare Theories and Welfare Regimes: Locating China’s Welfare at a Time of Change - Globalisation, Welfare Regimes and Welfare Changes: Locating Social policy in China in a Global Context - China’s Welfare Regime: Institutional framework for social welfare and social policy in China in a Global World Part II: Social and Economic Reforms: Implications for Social Policy - China’s Economic Reforms: Development and Transformation - Social Development in China: Challenges for a Harmonious Society - China’s Welfare System: Changes and Problems Part III: Specific Social Policy in China - Social Security and Poverty Reduction - Health Care Policy with particular respect to Urban Health Care Reforms - Population Ageing and Elderly Care - Professionalization of Social Work Part IV: Conclusion and Course Evaluation - Social Welfare and Social Policy in China: Which Way Ahead?
