title: Social Theories, Social Welfare and Social Work
requirements: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme, MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education, MA Programme in Social Policy and MA Programme in Social Service Management.
description: This course aims to examine the classical and contemporary social theories, particularly the evolution of the theories of modernism and postmodernism in the domain of social science. It also investigates the changing concepts and functions of social welfare that transform from the residual conception of social welfare that emphasizes self-reliance, informal support, charity and subsistence to the institutional conception of social welfare that stresses collective responsibilities, community care and development of human potentials. The major focus is to help students examine and critically analyze the implications of changing social theories on the development of social welfare and social work practice.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, it is expected that students would be able to:a)  identify significant intellectual trends in modern and postmodern social theories which have shaped the context for social welfare and social work practice;b)  comprehend the changing concepts and functions of social welfare, particularly amidst the rapid social, economic and political changes in the last few decades of the past century and in the new millennium;c)  reflect on the opportunities and challenges of social work in solving social problems and meeting needs under changing social conditions, with emphasis on the plight of vulnerable groups in society; andd)  recognize the relevance of knowledge on social theories to current issues and future development of social welfare and social work in Hong Kong.

Conclusion: Directions for Theory & Practice in Social Welfare and Social Work- Cross-cultural social welfare and social work? static, passive and dynamic models- Modeling new directions for social welfare and social work

title: Research in Social Welfare and Social Work
requirements: For students in Master of Social Work
description: This course is designed to provide the students with an understanding and appreciation of scientific and evidence-based approach to build knowledge for professional social work practice and evaluate practice in a variety of social services settings. Research processes examine in stages from problem formulation to analyses. The course focuses on how research problems are formulated, hypotheses or research questions are derived, the specific designs that practice researchers may use in addressing given research topics, and data collection and analysis approaches, and evaluating the research of others. The theoretical concepts, approaches, methods and issues in qualitative and quantitative research are covered.

title: Advanced Social Work Practice
requirements: for students in Master of Social Work
description: This course aims to help students understand the contemporary theories and knowledge of social work practice as well as the application of these theories in working with individuals, couples, families, groups, organizations and/or communities. The current state of social work practice in different settings and with various target populations will be discussed.

title: Social Innovation and Innovative Practice for Social Work
requirements: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme, MA Programme in Social Policy and MA Programme in Social Service Management.
description: This course prepares students to learn from the emerging practices of social innovations and innovative practices in tackling local and global challenges and uncertainties. Special attention will be given to the innovation and practices performed by social workers and social service agencies. Social innovation means accomplishing more with less, working together, leveraging resources, sharing data, and creating models for change that are sustainable. Social innovation is a broad concept and practice that could be implemented through social intrapreneurship or social entrepreneurship. Innovative practice means the introduction of new ideas, services, processes, procedures or structures into a system or organization to make a change for good. The innovative practice is a process moving internally designed or externally created knowledge into action. The essence of social innovation and innovative practice for social work is a process of planned social change in creating social values while its ultimate goal is to induce significant social impacts for the betterment of people’s quality of life.In this course, students will acquire knowledge, strategies and practice models of social innovations, social intrapreneurship, and social entrepreneurship. The scope of social innovations includes those in NGOs, non-profit organizations, communities, business and public sector. Experiential learning, such as site/ programme visits, dialogue with social entrepreneurs, social intrapreneurs or service users, will be integrated along the course delivery. The course will provide inspirations as well as know-how for students who would like to develop innovative actions to change society.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to• Realise how social innovations target social issues while creating social values through innovative strategies in social service sector;• Recognize the basic know-how of social innovation and innovative practices such as design thinking, community or civic engagement, collaboration, prototyping and lean start-up;• Apprehend how social intrapreneurs make use of innovative practice in social service agencies and NGOs;• Understand how social innovations and innovative practices leverage social workers’ impact to catalyze changes in community, and the broader social, economic and political spheres. • Critically evaluate how social innovations and innovative practices can fulfil the objectives, mission and values of social work profession.• Develop personal competences and be prepared to be a social innovator / social intrapreneur/ social entrepreneur in workplace, community and global environment.

title: Mental Health and Mental Disorders

requirements: For students of Master of Social Work (MSW), MA in Family Counselling and Family Education (MAFCFE), MA in Social Service Management (MASSM), MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare (MPhil-PhD) and Master of Social Science in Social Work (MSSc)
description: The purpose of this course is to enable students to acquire the knowledge and skills in conducting programme evaluation for human service programmes. The course will examine programme evaluation as an integral part of professional practice within the human services, and will introduce students to the concepts and methods in conducting programme evaluation from the conceptualization stage to the outcome stage of human service programmes. Special topics such as cost-effectiveness analysis, cost-benefit analysis, development of performance indicators, statistical process control, benchmarking, reengineering, single-subject designs, group designs, etc., will be discussed, and issues related to conducting programme evaluation for human services will be examined.
outcome: 1. Evaluate the major paradigms and models of program evaluation;2. Possess skills in finding and reviewing relevant literature in conducting program evaluation;3. Digest and scrutinize academic and professional program evaluation reports;4. Apply program evaluation concepts and tools in their professional and daily work practices;5. Design and conduct independent program evaluations for social programs that they are6. familiar with; and7. Generate findings based on quantitative and qualitative evaluation methods.
syllabus: - Introduction and Course Overview - Typology of Program Evaluation- Process of Program Evaluation - Introduction to Formative Design - Introduction to Summative Design I - Introduction to Summative Design II - Measurement and Research Design- Data Analysis- Presenting evaluation findings- Building up model for change

title: Social Welfare and Social Policy
requirements: For students in MA in Social Service Management, MSSc in Social Work and MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare
description: The course aims at helping students to examine the changing conceptions of social welfare, major theories of social welfare and social policy, the role and functions of social welfare in meeting needs and tackling social problems. Major social welfare systems of the West and East Asia (Hong Kong, China, etc.) will be introduced. The course will put emphasis on the development of social welfare programmes in Hong Kong in relation to poverty, unemployment, family problems and other social deprivations. Social work as a helping profession will be discussed, with particular attention on how they address and advocate for the cause of the vulnerable populations.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, the students will be able to:1. Discuss the relationship between private troubles and public issues.2. Discuss the changing concepts of social welfare.3. Understand basic values and philosophy underlying social welfare.4. Have basic knowledge in social policy planning, process, analysis and evaluation.5. Develop a social and macro view on social work practice.6. Make use of the knowledge acquired in class to discuss and assess current policypractice and social welfare program in Hong Kong critically.

title: Professional Values and Legal Knowledge in Social Work Practice
requirements: For students in MSSc in Social Work
description: This course helps students develop into ethical social workers and equips them with adequate legal knowledge. It helps students understand the philosophical foundation, practice principles, professional values and ethics of the social work profession. The course also introduces students to the Basic Law, the legal system in Hong Kong and the laws relevant to social work practice such as families, workers’ rights, and criminal justice, etc. Discussion will focus on the application of social work values and ethics in contexts, values and ethical dilemmas, as well as the legal implications on social work practice.
outcome: 1. Understood the historical development and professionalization of social work; 2. Identified with the philosophical foundation, practice principles and core values of social work; 3. Acquired an understanding of the ethical principles which guide social work practice; 4. Possessed basic knowledge about the legal system in Hong Kong; 5. Become familiar with significant ordinances related to social work practice; and, 6. Comprehended the legal implications on social work practice.
syllabus: - Nature of Social Work  - Historical development & Professionalization of social work - Definition of social work: Purpose, function and roles of social work - Legal System  - Laws Relating to Juvenile - Laws Relating to Family - Laws Relating to Human Rights  - Philosophical base and core values of social work  - Anti-oppressive practice and Ethical misconduct  - Ethical decision making framework

title: Social Policy and Social Welfare in Hong Kong and East Asia
requirements: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme and MA Programme in Social Policy.
description: The course aims at helping students to understand the nature, features, development, dilemmas and future prospects of social policy and social welfare in Hong Kong and East Asia. It looks at whether and how far social policy and social welfare in East Asia are different from those of the Western welfare states in terms of role and functions of state and society in the arrangement of welfare, culture and social values, policy instruments, and outcome measures. The social welfare systems in East Asia, in particular with that of Hong Kong in comparison with the rest will be highlighted. The students will be benefited from the comparative perspective for an understanding of the specific context where social policy in Hong Kong and East Asia has developed and the challenges it now faces amidst growing social disparities and economic globalization.
outcome: At the end of the course, students are able to understand the basic features of social policy and welfare systems in Hong Kong and East Asia and their underlying dynamics of development and challenges. They are able to practise the skills of reviewing literature and policy documents, classifying and diagnosing problems and issues, and undertaking secondary data analysis, and assessing social policy and welfare systems of Hong Kong and East Asia. Moreover, students are able to refer to ethical judgement on the social settlements which social policy and welfare systems are important components.
syllabus: - An introduction to the concepts of public welfare, welfare states, and social work, human needs, and different perspectives of social welfare - An introduction to the concepts, definitions, philosophy, professional values and practices of social work; the relationship between social work and social policy - An overview of social policy and welfare systems in East Asia, understand the social values of Confucian welfare relating to the development of social policy - Comparative approaches of social policy, East Asia welfare systems in comparative perspective  - Hong Kong: the development of welfare system, its basic features and social policy issues and approaches - Japan: the development of the welfare state system, personal social services, welfare-state regime - Taiwan: The transformation of authoritarian, social insurance and corporatist welfare states; developmentalism and democratization, demographic challenges and globalization - South Korea: Social welfare policy: past and future development, changes in social welfare policies - Macau: The development of social welfare system, its basic features and social policy issues and approaches - Singapore: Developmentalism, corporatism, capital-investment state, asset-based social policy, whither welfare state

title: Human Behaviour and the Social Environment
requirements: For students in MSSc Social Work, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare
description: The course aims to enable students to understand human growth and behaviour throughout the entire life-span from pregnancy to death within different socio-cultural contexts, including family, group, organization and community settings. The basic concepts, theories, and research findings on human growth and behaviour will be introduced. Particular attention will be given to the application of related knowledge to social work practice. The course serves to introduce students to the physical, psychological and socio-cultural aspects of human growth and behaviour and the mutual influences among individuals, families, groups, and the environment. Developmental issues and problems with reference to the different life stages will also be covered.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able: 1. To critically review the various biopsychosocial theories and perspectives which recognize the interaction between human behavior and the social environment. 2. To demonstrate knowledge of human growth and behavior throughout the life span from pregnancy to death. 3. To demonstrate understanding of the influence of interactions among individuals as well as the interaction between individuals and families, groups, organizations, communities, institutions, and larger systems. 4. To critically assess human developmental needs, problems and hazards in different life stages with relation to social work practice. 5. To apply various biopsychosocial theories and perspectives to explain current social issues in Hong Kong. 6. To demonstrate understanding of the role research plays in generating, supporting, and revising knowledge and the relative gap of evidence across theories and populations.
syllabus: - Understanding human behaviour in the social environment - An integrative multidimensional framework for assessing current and developmental concerns - Theoretical perspectives on human development - Biological, psychological and social development during the following stages:  : pregnancy  : infancy and toddlerhood  : early childhood  : middle childhood  : adolescence  : early adulthood  : middle adulthood  : late adulthood

title: Organizational Theories for Social Service Agencies
requirements: For students of MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme and MA Programme in Social Service Management.
description: This course equips students for social service management functions from an organizational theory perspective. It enhances the students’ ability to analyse and reflect on the key issues in social service management in their social service context by furnishing them with multiple theoretical perspectives of organizational theories and conceptualizations of social service agencies. Supporting the students to face the challenges ahead, this course provides an overview of social service management functions, including service planning, people management, quality management, service monitoring and evaluation as well as accountability.
outcome: After accomplishing this course, students will be able to: Describe the development of organization and organizational theories. Identify the nature and characteristics of social service organization and reflect on the implications for social service management.  Apply different theoretical perspectives to explain and reflect on management practice in social service organization. Analyse contemporary challenges in managing social service organizations form multiple theoretical perspectives. Provide recommendations for enhancing social service management.
syllabus: Emergence and evolution of organization and organization theory Organization theory: Multiple perspectives Social service agencies as organizations: Multiple conceptualizations  Leadership and people management Strategic service planning Quality management Service evaluation Accountability

title: Integrated Social Work Practice I
requirements: For students in MSSc Social Work, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare
description: This course is the first of three sequential courses on integrated social work practice. It helps students to examine the philosophy, values, perspectives and the helping process of integrated social work practice and to acquire the knowledge and basic skills necessary in working with individuals and families. The multidimensional context in which intervention occurs will be emphasized. Selected practice theories and models to guide intervention with individuals and families will be introduced.
outcome: Students are expected to acquire up-to-date social work knowledge, and skills ; withgreater ability in critical and independent thinking in case formulation andassessment of needs, preparing them to have more confidence for fieldworkplacement. Our graduates will identify with the humanistic values and ethics of thesocial work profession, have more awareness about the importance of usinginnovative means in meeting needs of clients and keep abreast of current social issues.

title: Integrated Social Work Practice II
requirements: For students in MSSc Social Work, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare; Prerequisite: SOWK5951
description: This course is the second of three sequential courses on integrated social work practice. It aims to help students to acquire knowledge and skills in social group work and understand the roles and functions of social worker in working with multi-client system. Apart from understanding group dynamics and group process, the application of group work approaches and models with diverse clienteles will be explored. Prerequisite: SOWK5951.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to: 1. understand the nature, principles and knowledge base of social group work; 2. identify various stages of group development, and the roles of a social worker in respective stage; 3. understand the different conceptual models in social group work practice; 4. familiarize with group dynamics, and understand how they can be used to achieve the social work objectives; 5. appreciate the application of the group work method in working with different clientele groups; and 6. plan for a group and review group achievement.
syllabus: 1. An overview of social group work  2. Knowledge base of social group work  3. Conceptual Models in Social Group Work  4. Therapeutic / Change Factors in Social Group Work  5. Ethics, roles and leadership of group worker  6. Group Dynamics  7. Group Development Stages  8. Purposive use of activities and programs  9. Important tasks in different stages of a group  10. Group evaluation 11. Application of group work with diverse clientele Readings

title: Integrated Social Work Practice III
requirements: For students in MSSc Social Work, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare; Prerequisite: SOWK5951
description: This course is the last of three sequential courses on integrated social work practice. It aims to develop students’ competence for community-based practice. It stresses the skills, techniques and strategies required to mobilize both people and resources to solve social problems at organizational and community level. It examines values and ethical dilemmas facing professional social workers in organizations, communities and policymaking arenas. The social planning and social reform aspects of social work practice are underscored in seeking change to cope with individual, family, and community problems. Laws concerning petition, public assembly and social action in Hong Kong will be introduced in the course.
outcome: Students are expected to learn the followings: 1. Understanding the concept of community and how to assess community needs  2. Knowing different models of and perspectives in community work practices and their application in Hong Kong 3. Acknowledging tactics and strategies in empowering & building up the capacity of the community 4. Appreciating how knowledge be put into practice in the specific social contexts
syllabus: - Understanding Community - Understanding Community Work - Community Need Assessment - Perspectives in Working with Community - Community Practice I:   : Advocacy  : Social Action - Community Practice II:    : Policy Planning  : Community Capacity Development  - Community Practice III:   : Empowerment  : Neighbourhood Work - Community Practice IV:   : Community Needs & Strategy Formation  - Community Practice V:  : Community Group Work & Organisation Development  - Community Practice VI:  : Community Care & Networking  : Social Capital & Networking

title: Social Work Field Laboratory
requirements: For students in MSSc Social Work
description: This course is a pre-placement preparation course. It aims to prepare students to make constructive use of field instruction. Laboratory training format is adopted in which experiential and reflective learning are emphasized. The emphases of the course are helping students to reflect on social work values and ethics; understand the meaning and nature of field instruction; get hold of essential communication skills; and acquire basic intervention skills. Students will be facilitated to reflect on their attitudes and styles in helping, and to develop more sensitivity and acceptance towards human nature.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, the students should be able to:  1. understand the meaning of help and develop more sensitivity and acceptance toward human nature and the uniqueness of individuals; 2. reflect on their basic attitudes in the helping process and have more capacity for self-awareness; 3. possess basic knowledge and communication skills in working with individuals and groups; 4. acquire skills in community need assessment; 5. examine and discuss direct practice issues in the context of local social service settings; and 6. appreciate the meaning of field instruction and make constructive use of it.
syllabus: - Introduction - Values and ethics - Briefing on community study project - Use of written work - Use of field instruction - Practicing in local culture and service settings - Programme evaluation

title: Social Service Management Project I
requirements: For students of MA Programme in Social Service Management, Master of Social Work
description: This course expects students to select and investigate one aspect of social service management practice in their employing organizations. The aim of the course is to engage students in critically examining the nature and characteristics of the selected aspect of social service management practice and propose innovative ideas and approaches for policy change and organizational improvement. In the process of conducting this project, students will, under the supervision of the course instructor, have the opportunity to learn research methods and further advance their understanding and integration of knowledge in social service management.
outcome: At the end of the course, students should be able to perform the following: 1. Apply organizational and management theories for analyzing specific organizational issues;  2. Critically assess management practices and issues in social service organizations;  3. Apply knowledge and techniques of scientific inquiry in developing social service management projects; and 4. Develop proposal for an evidence-based social service management study project.
syllabus: - Defining a Social Service Management Project (SSMP) - Planning a Research Project and Deciding a Topic - Research Design: Understanding Methodologies  - Qualitative Research Method: A Case Study Design  - Conceptual framework and Research Questions - Data Collection

title: Macro Social Work Practice: Strategic Planning
requirements: For students in MA in Social Service Management, MPhil - PhD in Social Welfare, MA in Social Policy, MSSc in Social Work and Master of Social Work
description: This course provides students with an opportunity to develop an understanding and appreciation of strategic planning as a dimension of macro social work practice used to promote planned change in communities and organizations pertaining to policies, organizational development, programme directions, service innovation, community problem-solving, and so on. Students will be introduced to the basic concepts and strategies, scopes and emphases, methods and processes, as well as techniques, skills and tools of strategic planning that may be used in human service organizations of diverse settings, clienteles, or auspices. Emphasis will be placed on the design of an action project of strategic planning.
outcome: 1. recognize the theoretical orientation of different schools on strategy formulation and examine the pros and cons of various approaches in strategic planning 2. apply methods and skills to formulate the strategic plan of an organization 3. conceptualize and analyze the social welfare scene in Hong Kong from a strategic perspective; and 4. possess the mindset of strategic thinking in performing their professional role as social workers and managers.

title: Human Resource Development in Social Services
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare, MA in Social Policy, MA in Social Service Management, MSSc in Social Work and Master of Social Work
description: This course aims to equip students with knowledge and skills in developing human resources in the social welfare field and the social service sector in an effective manner. Issues related to the human resource development process including staff recruitment, selection, deployment, training, performance appraisal, and recruitment will be discussed, and topics on leadership, team-building, staff motivation, and Enhanced Productivity Programmes (EPP) will be examined with practice examples.

title: Social Enterprise
requirements: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme, MA Programme in Social Policy and MA Programme in Social Service Management.
description: This course introduces to students the field of social entrepreneurship and the best practices of mission-driven social ventures which aim to achieve a balance between meaningful social returns as well as sustainable or competitive financial returns through their products, services and other business practices. It also stimulates students to explore how social entrepreneurs can affect policy and facilitate system change. Entrepreneurial solutions to education, healthcare, environment, workforce development, international development and other large societal issues will be addressed through the sharing of experiences by successful practitioners/funders of social entrepreneurial organizations. The course is valuable to anyone who may want to design or lead a mission-driven social enterprise, or want to contribute time and energy to help build the social sector through strategic philanthropy and social investing.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to - Better understand how social ventures work to blend disparate goals, how and why social entrepreneurs successfully fuse purpose and personal passion in business, and how visions and values are embedded in organizational culture; - Become familiar with the practices of social enterprises in different sectors, of various sizes, and with different visions; - Better understand the key methods, strategies and models for social entrepreneurial organizations to succeed; - Better understand how social enterprises leverage their work and impact to influence policy and systems change; - Become familiar with a variety of approaches and tools to measure organizational performance and social impact of social entrepreneurial ventures.
syllabus: - Development of Social Enterprise - Defining Social Enterprise - Key Models of Social Enterprise - Social Impact Assessment of Social Enterprise - Overview of Social Entrepreneurship - Site Visits to Social Enterprises in HK - Class Discussion of Assigned Readings, Sharing of Site Visits, & Developing a Social Enterprise Business Plan - Ethical Principles and Concerns - Opportunity Seeking and Alliance Building - Risk Management - Social Marketing - Group Presentation on Business Plan

title: Groupwork Practice with Families
requirements: For students in MA Family Counselling & Family Education
description: The course examines the theories of group dynamics and groupwork skills in working with different types of families. Focuses will be placed on how to use group as a mutualaid system to facilitate the growth of children, parents and families; alleviate isolation; and achieve problem-solving insight. Attention will be given to the role of group worker and his/her purposeful use of group process and programmes to enable individuals and groups to develop effective knowledge and skills to address their own concerns in different contexts, i.e., parents’ groups, groups for children with behavioural or emotional disturbance, volunteer leadership training groups, skills in working with parent-teacher association, etc.
outcome: 1. Acquire knowledge concerning key topics of group therapy theory and practice including: group planning, needs assessment, group goals, group composition, group structure, group development, group dynamics, group leadership, therapeutic factors, group programme design, group intervention and group evaluation. 2. Increase sensitivity towards current research findings related to groupwork practices and enhance integration of theory and practice in group applications. 3. Develop practical skills in working with families and family members using group-work intervention and how to deal with practice issues in group process. 4. Enhance ethical awareness and cultural competence in group work practices.
syllabus: - Introduction and overview, Perspectives in working with families in groups; Use of systemic perspective - Parallel groups with issues related to pre-group assessment, micro and macro group design  - Couple groups  - 5A programme logic model 5B Multiple family group - Multiple family group  - Interventions: Working with individuals in groups  - Critical Incident model and working with conflicts in groups - Psychodynamic perspective & working with emotions in groups - Group stage, Group leadership, Working with emotions in groups

title: Family Counselling/Family Education Project
requirements: For students in MA Family Counselling & Family Education
description: This course aims to develop students’ professional competence by helping them integrate theory with practice. In order to facilitate students’ learning, students have to choose an area of interest in family counselling or family education for in-depth study and analysis. Students are required to critically examine the underlying assumptions and operational application of the selected family education or family counselling topic and discuss innovative approaches for improvement. At the end of the course, students are expected to produce a project report and to present their projects in class for intellectual exchange, experiential review and theoretical integration.

title: Social Policy Research I
requirements: For students in MPhil - PhD in Social Welfare and MA in Social Policy
description: Knowledge of fundamental social policy research skills is very important for modern social policy practitioners. Such knowledge increases social policy practitioners’ ability to understand and utilize research findings to inform and enhance their practice and provide the skills necessary to plan and carry out research related to social policy practice. Social policy practitioners also need to know how to use exiting knowledge and to assume leadership in expanding knowledge that identifies effective policy and evidence-based intervention program. The purpose of this course is to develop students’ knowledge of general research in social policy level, particularly in quantitative research methods. Emphasis will be placed on the topics related to development of research questions and hypotheses, evidence-based social policy approach, validity and reliability of measurement, research designs, sampling methods, social surveys, and quantitative data.
outcome: This course aims to help students understand the nature and methods of social policy research. Students who successfully complete this course will be expected to be able to: 1. Develop a beginning understanding of the conceptual foundations and methodological tools of quantitative social research and its application to field of social policy.  2. Discuss how research informs social work practice and service delivery, and social welfare policy.  3. Select appropriate quantitative research methods to study a given vulnerable population or policy problem. 4. Locate, understand, critically analyze, and utilize professional social policy research reports and articles.  5. Identify and discuss ethical issues related to research design and the reporting and use of research results.  6. Discuss issues related to sampling, measurement, data collection, and internal and external threats to validity.  7. To increase students’ awareness of how methodological issues being debated, particularly in the filed of social policy. 8. To enhance class participants’ ability to contribute to and strengthen the scientific based of social policy and social work profession.
syllabus: - Development of research questions and hypotheses  - Evidence-based social policy approach  - Validity and reliability of measurement  - Research designs, sampling methods, social surveys, and quantitative data

title: Comparative Social Security Systems
requirements: For students in MPhil - PhD in Social Welfare, MSSc in Social Work, Master of Social Work, MA in Social Policy and MA in Social Service Management
description: This course aims to help students acquire a comparative perspective on social security systems. It will examine the cross-national variations in the characteristics, traditions, major programmes and outcomes of different social security systems. Emphasis will also be placed on the current issues and debates such as the impact of globalization and population ageing, affordability and equity, reform strategies in general as well as specific programmes – social assistance, health care and pensions.

requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare, MA in Social Service Management, MA in Social Policy, MA in Family Counselling and Family Education, Master of Social Work and MSSc in Social Work
description: This course aims to provide students with an opportunity to examine some of the current issues and important developments in the social policy field, with the help of concepts and theories in social work and social policy, and in the context of Chinese societies under rapid socioeconomic transformation. For more in-depth understanding of and reflection on the aforementioned areas, a specific topic under the course will be selected for the students to take in their studies.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will have acquired in-depth knowledge on topics related to current issues and important developments in the social policy field.

title: Social Policy Dissertation
requirements: For students in MA Social Policy
description: This course requires students to write a dissertation on an approved topic in social policy under faculty guidance. The emphasis of this dissertation is on current social policy and social development issues in China. The dissertation should be on policy analysis or policy implementation, together with social problem description. It should demonstrate linkage between social policy concepts and theories on one side, and actual policy issues on the other. It may also draw on students’ own practical experience.
outcome: At the end of the project, students should be able to: - Identify a selected social problem or policy issue and delineate its significance; - Formulate a topic with clear rationale/justifications related to the selected social problem or policy issue to capture critical concerns; - Outline the linkage among research objectives, research questions, theoretical framework, and research methods learnt from other courses; - Apply techniques of scientific inquiry to investigate the chosen topic; and - Present the methodology, findings, discussion, and recommendations clearly and systematically in class presentation and in the dissertation.

title: Social Policy Research II
requirements: For students of MA Programme in Social Policy, MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education, Master of Social Science Programme in Social Work and Master of Social Work Programme
description: This course is the second social policy research course. It provides students with basic concepts of qualitative research methods and their application in social policy research. This course will enhance the analytical ability of students to identify the relevant research methods and their strengths and weaknesses in doing social policy research. Specific topics include: qualitative policy research, descriptive qualitative analysis, methods of research design, case study research, field research and research ethics. The research process such as formulation of research question in relation to public policies, theoretical sampling, qualitative data collection and analysis, and methods for secondary analysis and comparative approach will also be emphasized. This course will also examine the uses of qualitative methods for policy reviews and evaluation purposes.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, the student should: 1. Be able to identify and critically appraise research, designs and qualitative methods appropriate for the investigation of social problems or evaluating social policies; 2. Understand ethical issues in conducting qualitative social research; 3. Be able to develop and articulate the logic of different qualitative research methods and understand their strengths and weaknesses in doing social policy research;  4. Demonstrate at beginning competence in data collection methods and analysis such as observation and interviewing, secondary analysis and comparative approach; 5. Develop self-reflective and self-critical attitudes in conducting social policy research.
syllabus: - Qualitative policy research - Descriptive qualitative analysis  - Methods of research design  - Case study research - Field research - Research ethics  - Research process such as formulation of research question in relation to public policies, theoretical sampling, qualitative data collection and analysis - Methods for secondary analysis and comparative approach - Uses of qualitative methods for policy reviews and evaluation purposes

title: Applied Statistics for Social Work and Social Welfare
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Social Welfare, MSSc Social Work, Master of Social Work, MA Fam Counselling & Fam Edu, MA Social Policy and MA Social Service Management.
description: The course is designed to introduce advanced statistical methods that are used in data analysis and social work research. Both statistical theories and inference techniques will be covered. This is an applied Statistics course for Social Work and Social Welfare, with focuses on statistical theories, probability distributions, bivariate and multivariate analysis. SPSS, a statistical analysis software package, will be used to provide students with knowledge and skills necessary to conduct quantitative social work research.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students are expected to be able to: 1. Understand the theories of statistical inferences and apply the appropriate models in different settings to answer research questions in social work; 2. Master skills in conducting the statistical analyses of data using SPSS.  3. Master skills that will enable them to interpret and document SPSS output and report results in a scholarly manner. 4. Conduct multivariate statistical analyses and extend the analyses methods to social work research practice.
syllabus: This course includes different techniques in statistical inference, particularly in multivariate analysis, with the discussion of theories for students to evaluate the plausibility of the assumptions in the inference process.  Main topics include: #Apply T-TEST for Social Work and Social Welfare • Single sample T-Test • Two sample T-Tests # Apply Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) for Social Work and Social Welfare • One-way ANOVA • Two-way and multiple-way ANOVA • ANCOVA # Apply Correlation and Regression for Social Work and Social Welfare • Simple Regression • Multiple Regression • Logistic Regression #Non-parametric tests # Apply Factor Analyses & Path Analyses for Social Work and Social Welfare • Exploratory Factor Analyses • Confirmatory Factor Analyses • Validity and reliability issues

title: Digital Transformation in Social Services
requirements: Programmes allowed to enrol: MA Fam Counselling & Fam Edu, MA Social Policy, MA Social Service Management, MSSc Social Work, Master of Social Work and MPhil-PhD Social Welfare.
description: To address the digital transformation challenges faced by social services agencies, alignment of ICT strategy with organisation reality across all levels involves the development of a roadmap for ICT adoption and organisation transformation. Practitioners need knowledge and skills to grow their digital competency over time in adapting to the latest digital landscape for delivering more engaging social services. The purpose of this course is to help students navigate the digital transformation maze through sound program/project management in an evidence-based context. The main goals of digital transformation are needs and competencies assessment, workflow change, and system integration of logic models in supporting data driven decision making. Social service agencies have to put the data in order and equip operation staff with the needed knowledge and skills to function effectively and efficiently. Use of design thinking and lean startup approach will be integrated into digital social services development and implementation as covered in this course. Furthermore, students will learn to use no-code/low-code digital tools to implement a fully integrated data driven information management and service system. The completed system can be used for ongoing data collection, statistical analysis, and data visualisation for event promotion, service program tracking, volunteer recruitment, impact evaluation, donation accounting, and funding application.

title: Seminar on Selected Topics: Structural Family Therapy
requirements: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme and MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education.
description: This course examines the underlying philosophical assumptions, the major theoretical constructs and the application of structural family therapy in Hong Kong. Students will be helped to develop professional competence in working with different types of families in need and to be self-reflexive of their own personal style in helping. A critical review of structural family therapy especially in addressing the gender issue and the socio-cultural differences of different societies will be made.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, it is expected that students would be able to: 1. Critically examine the shift in perspective from modernism to postmodernism and its implications for family assessment and intervention 2. Acquire a systems perspective in conceptualizing the family in need 3. Recognize the contributions and constraints of structural family therapy in family assessment and intervention in different social service settings 4. Heighten their sensitivity and awareness in ethical, cultural and gender issues as well as the use of self in family assessment and intervention; and  5. Link up the importance of larger social systems intervention with family therapy in helping.

title: Seminar on Selected Topics: Marital Therapy
requirements: For students in MSSc in Social Work and MA in Family Counselling & Family Education
description: This course aims to help students understand different approaches in working with couples with marital distress. It examines the underlying philosophical assumptions, the major theoretical constructs and the application of marital therapy in Hong Kong. It also aims to enhance knowledge and skills of students in dealing with marital impasse and working with emotional reactivity of couples. Apart from helping students integrate the theoretical concepts of marital therapy in practice, the course also helps students develop competence in working with couples and cultivate their personal style of helping. Focuses will be lay on the application of marital therapy in working with couples with various concerns such as extra marital affairs, issues of family origin, or one party suffering from depression.

title: Professional Ethics and Legal Issues in Marriage and Family Therapy
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Social Welfare, MSSc Social Work, Master of Social Work, MA Fam Counselling & Fam Edu, MA Social Policy and MA Social Service Management.
description: This course will study the ethical and legal issues in marriage and family therapy in various international and local contexts. The course aims at helping students to acquire knowledge about important ethical and legal issues in practice as a marriage and family therapist. The multicultural competence of students will be fostered to enable them to work with people in diversity. Students will be helped to reflect on their personal values and to show commitment to professional values in practice of marriage and family therapy.

title: Practical Skills in Marriage and Family Therapy
requirements: For students of Master of Arts Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education (Specialization: Accredited Programme on Marriage and Family Therapy) only
description: This course equips students with the essential skills and techniques in clinical assessment and diagnosis; treatment planning and case management; and therapeutic interventions in marriage and family therapy. Special attention will be given to the integrative use of relevant models and theories as well as the adoption of cultural and gender perspective in practice. The course is valuable to helping professionals who want to acquire core competencies in couples and family work.

title: Clinical Internship in Marriage and Family Therapy I
requirements: For students of Master of Arts Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education (Specialization: Accredited Programme on Marriage and Family Therapy) only
description: This course provides an opportunity for students to learn marriage and family therapy through clinical practice with individuals, couples and families. Students are required to have internship in community agencies or public institutions under clinical supervision of an approved supervisor. The course focuses on the development of basic assessment skills, integration of theories into practice, and personal and professional growth of students. The major goal of the internship is for the preparation of students to practice marriage and family therapy for individuals, couples and families in different social services, healthcare and educational settings upon graduation.

title: Clinical Internship in Marriage and Family Therapy II
requirements: For students of Master of Arts Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education (Specialization: Accredited Programme on Marriage and Family Therapy) only;Prerequisite: SOWK6218
description: (This course is the continuation of SOWK6218 Clinical Internship in Marriage and Family Therapy I)This course provides an opportunity for students to learn marriage and family therapy through clinical practice with individuals, couples and families. Students are required to have internship in community agencies or public institutions under clinical supervision of an approved supervisor. The course focuses on the development of basic assessment skills, integration of theories into practice, and personal and professional growth of students. The major goal of the internship is for the preparation of students to practice marriage and family therapy for individuals, couples and families in different social services, healthcare and educational settings upon graduation.

title: Field Instruction I (400 hours of supervised practice)
requirements: For students in MSSc Social Work; Prerequisite: SOWK5951, SOWK5952, SOWK5953 and SOWK5955
description: The course provides opportunities for students to put theories into practice. Students will be placed in a social service setting for supervised practice. Through exposure to reallife situations and a refl ective learning process, the course aims to help students to apply principles and methods of social work intervention in practice, to make differential use of community resources, to function effectively in organizational context, to develop their professional qualities and competence, and then to become an independent professional social worker.
outcome: After the first placement, students should be able to: 1. Demonstrate good knowledge and understanding of factors influencing the service development and social work practice in the placement agency and the service setting; 2. Identify with and apply social work values, assumptions and principles in practice; 3. Self-examine and reflect on learning and practice experience; 4. Make good use of social science knowledge in understanding and analysing human behaviour in social environment; and 5. Apply basic helping skills in different stages of social work interventions
syllabus: To be eligible for registration as a Registered Social Worker, students are required to undertake a total of not less than 900 hours of fieldwork which includes:  1. 100 hours of pre-placement preparation training sessions (compulsory attendance), and  2. Two field placements each achieving not less than 400 hours supervised practice during the course of study  Each student will be placed in two different service settings in different social welfare service agencies to fulfil the requirement for supervised practice. Non-local field placement is also offered in order to help students develop an international perspective and world vision. Apart from direct social work practice, relevant agency visits, community visits and participation in agency staff conferences are also encouraged in the field placement to enable students to become familiar with their field of service and enlarge their practice experiences.
required_readings: Readings are assigned by individual field instructors according to different service natures of different placement units.
recommended_readings: Readings are assigned by individual field instructors according to different service natures of different placement units.

requirements: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme, MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education, MA Programme in Social Policy and MA Programme in Social Service Management.
description: The course strengthens students' knowledge related to social work, social service management or social welfare. Topics of this course depend on expertise of the instructor.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will have acquired in-depth knowledge on topics related to social work, social service management or social welfare.

title: Youth Culture and Youth Work
requirements: For students in MA in Social Policy, MSSc in Social Work, and Master of Social Work
description: This course aims to provide students with an in-depth understanding of youth culture and youth work in global and local contexts. It explores different concepts of youth and their theoretical and ideological foundations, and discusses key themes in studies of youth culture including youth in society (e.g. citizenship, school-to-work transition, social inclusion and exclusion), youth cultural practice (e.g. subcultures, globalization, consumption and identity), and youth in community (e.g. democratic participation, youth and public space). The course furthermore examines approaches to youth work in contemporary societies, with emphases on reflective understanding of the problems and needs of today’s youth, and critical appraisal of major youth work models. Current policy issues related to human rights and well-being of young people will also be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students are expected to: 1) Have an in-depth understanding of youth culture and youth work in global and local contexts 2) Understand different concepts of youth and their theoretical and ideological foundations 3) Understand various approaches to youth work in contemporary societies 4) Acquire knowledge on current policy issues related to human rights and well-being of young people

Principles of Youth Work/Program - Youth Work Models/ Evidence-based youth work  - Youth Services in Hong Kong

title: Family Intervention
requirements: For students in MSSc Social Work
description: This course aims to help students acquire knowledge and skills in working with families. Specifically, it attempts to familiarize students with current major approaches in working with families, to acquire knowledge in family assessment and intervention, and to develop an integrative perspective in family practice. The implications of social changes on family, the changing family ideologies, gender issue in family, policies on family and the adequacy of family services will be critically examined with particular reference to the Hong Kong context.
outcome: Upon the completion of the course, the students are expected to be able to: 1. Understand the theoretical foundation, basic concepts and skills of major approaches in working with families that have been taught in the course. 2. Demonstrate understanding of knowledge in family assessment and intervention. 3. Develop an integrative perspective on family practice. 4. Critically examine the structural, ideological, and cultural issues in family interventions in Hong Kong.
syllabus: - Family-centered practice: The guiding framework of family intervention - Structural family interventions - Narrative family interventions and collective practice - Groupwork in Family intervention: Multiple family group/therapy - Exo- and Macro-level intervention of Family-centered Practice

title: Cognitive-behavioural Intervention
requirements: For students of Master of Social Science in Social Work and Master of Arts in Family Counselling and Family Education Programs
description: The course aims to examine human psychosocial problems from a cognitive-behavioural perspective. The reciprocal interaction among human cognition, behaviour and environment will be highlighted. The major schools of cognitive-behavioural therapies will be introduced and their applications in helping individuals and families will be covered. Application issues such as alliance building, homework compliance and adaptation of cognitive-behavioural intervention in local context will be discussed.

title: Solution-focused Approach
requirements: For Students of Master of Social Science in Social Work and Master of Arts in Family Counselling and Family Education students
description: This course examines the solution-focused approach within the family system framework and post-modern perspective. It helps students understand the basic assumptions and theoretical foundations of the approach, and gives specific principle for intervention. Apart from helping students integrate the theoretical concepts of solution-focused therapy in practice, the course also aims to help students develop professional competence and to expand their personal style of helping. Special attention will be paid to address the gender and class issues and the differential use of solution-focused therapy in the cultural context of Hong Kong.

title: Clinical Social Work Practice: Selected Approaches– Marriage & Family Therapy
requirements: For students of MSSc Programme in Social Work and MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education.
description: This course aims to provide an extensive review of the theoretical foundations of the various schools of marriage and family therapy, from modernism to post-modernism. The focus will be on unifying conceptual threads that integrate different approaches, including Bowenian, strategic, structural, experiential, solution-focused, and narrative. Techniques from various models that are applicable to family therapy with Chinese families will also be addressed. The teaching format includes lecture, videotaped segments of family interviews, role-play, and case discussion.

title: Social Work with People with Disabilities
requirements: For students of MSSc Social Work, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare, Master of Social Work, MA Fam Counselling & Fam Edu, MA Social Policy and MA Social Service Management.
description: Social workers who work with people with disabilities (PWDs) nowadays should have critical mind and self-reflective attitudes to meet the challenges from the changing field of disabilities. To enhance the quality of life of PWDs, social workers should have sensitivity to understand situations of individuals with disabilities, and have substantial knowledge of intervening in different levels of environments. Providing students an insightful learning process, this course uses interactive and experiential activities besides traditional one-way lectures. Guests, including person(s) with intellectual disabilities, person(s) with physical disabilities, their carers, and social workers, will be invited to share their life experience in class. This course introduces students to the paradigm shift in the international disability field, the evolution of services affecting PWDs, and contemporary approaches to provide services to PWDs.

title: Social Service Planning, Programme Development and Evaluation
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare and MSSc in Social Work
description: This course is crafted to equip students with an advanced understanding of social service management in terms of service planning, programme development and evaluation. It first prepares the students to analyse and reflect on the nature and characteristics of social service followed by grounding in social service value frameworks to address the purposes and functions of social service management. Further, it furnishes the students with essential theoretical knowledge and practice approaches for enhancing their capacity in social service management, including service and programme planning, resources management, quality management, programme monitoring and evaluation, as well as accountability.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:i.         Describe the nature and characteristics of social service and reflect on their implications for social service management.ii.         Apply the value frameworks to address critical issues in social service management. iIi.         Inform different theoretical perspectives of and practice approaches to social service management.iv.        Appraise advantages and limitations of different theoretical perspectives and practice approaches.v.        Provide recommendation(s) for enhancing social service management.
syllabus: Nature and characteristics of social service I Nature and characteristics of social service II Value frameworks: Participatory management in neoliberal and managerial social service context  Strategic service planning Programme planning and development logic  Programme management Programme monitoring and evaluation Accountability

title: Master of Social Science Project
requirements: For students in MSSc Social Work
description: The course requires students to write an individual project paper related to their field practicum. The paper aims to engage students in critically examination of practice theories and skills concerning needs and characteristics of target groups, goals of intervention, and programme design. In the process of writing the paper, students are required to apply knowledge of social work research in practice.

title: Youth:Risk and Resilience
requirements: For students in Master of Social Work, MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare and MSSc in Social Work
description: The course examines the differing perspectives of identifying at-risk youth. It aims to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the at-risk youth in the contexts of peer, family, school and community. With an emphasis on the integration of theory and practice, the course examines different approaches of working with at-risk youth, and analyzes psychological and social intervention strategies that may help in the development of youth resilience. Topical areas of particular relevance to work with youth such as sexuality, non-engaged youth, juvenile delinquency, substance abuse and positive youth development are examined.

title: Working with Children & Youth with Special Needs
requirements: For students of MPhil-PhD Programme in Social Welfare, MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme, MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education and MA Programme in Social Policy.
description: This course examines the nature and needs of children and youth with special needs including various physical disabilities, intellectual disability, specific learning difficulty, autistic spectrum, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. The assessment and interventions of these clients and their families will be introduced and the roles of various professionals working with these young people, especially, the role of social worker, will be examined. Relevant education, policy, medical and legal issues are discussed. It also initiates a critical discussion on the evidence-based practice which is built on up-to-date empirical findings in local context, and the challenge of social work intervention in Hong Kong.

title: Use of Arts, Dance and Experiential Learning in Social Work Practice
requirements: For students of MSSc Programme in Social Work, Master of Social Work Programme and MA Programme in Family Counselling and Family Education.
description: This course is designed to provide students with an understanding in using different creative media to enhance awareness, instill cognitive changes and facilitate personal growth of clients. The course utilizes the experiential learning theories to equip students with skills and knowledge in using arts, movement and creative media in various social service settings. Critical reflection about cultural implications in practice is emphasized.
outcome: - To equip students with knowledge about theory and knowledge in using arts, movement, creative media and experiential learning in various social work setting. - To enable students learning facilitation skills in using arts, movement, creative media and experiential learning in social work practice - To let the participants have critical reflection about use of art and experiential learning in Chinese cultural context - To stimulate students using arts, creative media and dance as narratives of representation and creativity, a means of working with clients in social work intervention
syllabus: - Use of Dance in Praxis - Illustrations of use of art in Praxis - Photovoice - Use of photography in Social work practice - Use of Arts and Dance in Social Work Practice - Research - Experiential Learning

title: Family-centered Social Work Practice
requirements: For students in Master of Social Work, MA Family Counselling & Family Education
description: This course aims to equip students with knowledge and skills in family-centered practice in social work practice. The underlying assumptions, theoretical concepts and helping principles of family-centered practice for assessment, formation of intervention goals and delineation of intervention strategies are discussed. The roles that social work practitioners play in the delivery of social welfare services in a variety of social work settings such as child protection system, medical and psychiatric settings, foster care, adoption and residential care are also examined.

title: Urban Social Work in Chinese Context
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD in Social Welfare, MA in Social Policy, MA in Social Service Management, MSSc in Social Work and Master of Social Work
description: This course aims to help students understand the development and current situation of social work in contemporary urban China and fully recognize the opportunity and challenges faced by social work in Chinese cities. The course content will include the pilot and model of social work service in different cities, changes in service delivery and funding, development of innovative social management and NGOs. Mainstream urban social work services on families and children, youth, senior citizens, disabled people and women will be introduced; other services on mobile population, labour and the poor will also be covered in the course.

title: Family-centered Practice in Mental Health Services
requirements: For students in Master of Social Work, MPhil-PhD Social Welfare
description: This course aims to equip students with knowledge and skills in family-centered practice for clients suffering from mental health problem and/ or mental disorders. The underlying assumptions, theoretical concepts and helping principles of family-centered practice for assessment, formation of intervention goals and delineation of intervention strategies are discussed. Emphasis is also placed on the discussion of contributions of gender and cultural perspectives in family social work practice.

title: Clinical Social Work Practice with Children and Youth with Mental Health Problems
requirements: For students in Master of Social Work, MA Family Counselling & Family Education
description: This course equips students with different intervention approaches (e.g. client-centered approach, family therapy, group work) in assessing and helping children and youth suffering from mental health problems and/ or mental disorders. It aims to enhance students’ awareness of the importance of evidence-based clinical practice in helping. It also aims to help students develop their model of practice which is contextually based.

title: Clinical Social Work Practice in Mental Health
requirements: for Master of Social Work (MSW) and Master of Arts (MA) in Family Counselling and Family Education students only
description: This course equips students with integrated and holistic approaches in assessing and helping clients suffering from mental health problems and/ or mental disorders. It aims to enhance students’ awareness of the importance of evidence-based clinical practice in helping. It also aims to help students develop their model of practice which is contextually based.

title: Social Work Research
requirements: For students in MSSc in Social Work
description: This course helps students understand the relationship between social research and social work practice. The basic concepts, approaches, methods and issues in qualitative and quantitative research will be introduced. The course will address the process of formulating research questions and hypotheses, methods of data collection, data analyses, and social work research ethics. Students will examine research methods associated with policy practice, clinical intervention and ethical issues.
outcome: This course aims to help students understand the nature and methods of social work research. Students who successfully complete this course will be expected to be able to:  1. Develop a beginning understanding of the conceptual foundations and methodological tools of quantitative and qualitative social research and its application to field of social work.  2. Discuss how research informs social work practice and service delivery, and social welfare policy.  3. Select appropriate quantitative and/or qualitative research methods to study a given vulnerable population or social problem.  4. Locate, understand, critically analyze, and utilize professional social work research reports and articles.  5. Identify and discuss ethical issues related to research design and the reporting and use of research results.  6. Discuss issues related to sampling, measurement, data collection, and internal and external threats to validity.  7. To increase students’ awareness of how methodological issues being debated, particularly in the filed of social work practice.  8. To enhance class participants’ ability to contribute to and strengthen the scientific based of social work profession.
syllabus: 1. Course introduction, overview, and scientific inquiry  2. Problem formation, literature review, & ethics  3. Conceptualization, operationalization  Measurement   Constructing questions  4. Causal inference  Research designs: pre-experimental & experimental   5. Sampling and survey research   6. Quantitative data analysis (1)  -Descriptive statistics  -Difference test (t-test, ANOVA)  7. Quantitative data analysis(2)  -Association test (chi-square and correlation)  -Linear regression  8. Qualitative Research

title: Master of Social Work Project
requirements: For students in Master of Social Work
description: This course aims to facilitate students’ professional competence by helping them integrate theory and practice. Students are required to choose an area of interest in their specific concentration for in-depth study and analysis. Students have to critically examine the needs and characteristics of the target groups, the influential social ideologies, related social policies, critical contextual factors and the interconnection of these elements in affecting the well-being of individual and family. In the process of the project, students also have the opportunity to further integrate their knowledge of social work research and practice. According to the results of the study, students have to discuss innovative approaches for improvement or innovative service models in their project reports. In order to facilitate learning, students will be arranged in small groups.

title: Use of Information and Communication Technology in Social Services
requirements: For students in MA in Social Policy, MA in Social Service Management, MSSc in Social Work and Master of Social Work
description: This course aims to equip students with knowledge and skills in utilizing information and communication technologies (ICTs) to develop, operate, manage, and evaluate social services. The course will focus on the non-profit organizations and public administration contexts to teach and discuss how ICTs can be innovatively applied for social good, and how we can harness the new technologies to ensure their usage to be ethical and sustainable. No previous training in ICTs or computer science is required.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to: 1. Identify the information needs in providing social services, and discuss how ICT can improve the decision making process in social work practice at various levels. 2. Make proposal of ICT development project following relevant principles and processes 3. Identify and critically discuss the impacts of ICT development in society and social service provision.

title: Budgeting and Financial Planning in Social Service Organizations
requirements: For students in MA in Social Service Management, MA in Social Policy, MSSc in Social Work and Master of Social Work
description: This course aims at helping students to understand the concepts, systems, and processes of budgeting and financial management in social service organizations within the local context and in mainland China. The course examines the nature and functions of budgeting and financial management in social service organizations, the similarities and differences of budgeting and financial management between for-profit and nonprofit organizations, the basic knowledge regarding budgeting and financial management in areas such as resource acquisition, distribution, control, recording, and reporting, the basic skills in budgeting and financial management including designing various forms of budgets, analyzing financial statements, raising funds, and writing grant proposals, and helps students gain an insight into recent trends and issues affecting budgeting and financial management for social service organizations and develop pertinent strategies to cater for these changes.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:  1. recognize function of financial management in social service organizations and make  use of financial information for decision making;  2. compare the similarities and differences of budgeting and financial management between for-profit and nonprofit organizations and examine the ethical issues involved in resource acquisition and allocation;  3. possess basic knowledge and skills on resource acquisition and development which include strategies on policy influence, fund raising, grant proposals writing;   4. master basic skills in developing various forms of budgets, analyzing financial statements and applying administrative policies and measures for financial control;   5. analyze the political and social factors which affect the decision making process in resource allocation and identify strategies to overcome current challenges faced by social service organizations in resource management.
